column2: In 1979, an ice storm that began December 31st, 1978, continued through New Years Day. Madison County was especially hard hit, and residents said this event was possibly the biggest in 50 years. ^In 1996, heavy snow fell across northwest Arkansas and eastern Oklahoma. 4 to 8 inches of snow were common, with up to 12 inches in extreme northwest Arkansas. ^In 2006, three fast-moving wildfires near Bristow burned thousands of acres and many structures. Several other fires occurred this day, including one near Muskogee that burned 16,000 acres.

In 1999, a severe winter storm brought freezing rain to northwest Arkansas and northeast Oklahoma. Carroll County, Arkansas was hard-hit by ice accumulations of up to half an inch. Travel was also nearly impossible. The Governor of Arkansas declared Carroll County one of six counties in northwest Arkansas eligible for disaster relief funds. That area also received 1 to 2 inches of snow.

In 2000, severe thunderstorms moved from southeast Oklahoma to northwest Arkansas, producing damaging winds and large hail. Eastern Latimer County between Wilburton and Red Oak received wind damage to several buildings and trees. The Auction House in Wilburton had its roof blown off, and other businesses had their windows broken. Several mobile homes and other structures were damaged.

In 1917, an F3 tornado killed 16 people and injured 20 when it destroyed a Choctaw Indian Baptist Mission school in Vireton, OK, 13 miles northeast of McAlester in Pittsburg County. All 16 killed were children, ranging from ages 6 to 18. ^In 1998, heavy rain fell across northeast Oklahoma and northwest Arkansas from the 4th-5th. 3 to 6 inches of rain were common, and Fayetteville's Drake Field had a 2-day rainfall total of 6.33 inches. Widespread flash flooding occurred, and most creeks and rivers overflowed their banks. The storm also produced 90 to 100 mph winds in some areas.

In 2005, winter storms and floods occurred in northeast Oklahoma and northwest Arkansas. Rain changed to freezing rain and sleet as cold air moved into the area. Ice accumulated on trees, power lines, and other surfaces. Heavy sleet also occurred in Osage, Pawnee, and Washington Counties, causing major travel problems. Flooding had occurred earlier in the day due to thunderstorms.

In 1988, from January 5th-7th, widespread heavy snow covered the entire area. This winter storm was one of the largest snowstorms for the southern U.S. in the 20th century. From the afternoon of the 5th until about 1AM on the 7th, 6 to 11 inches of snow fell in northwest Arkansas and over a foot fell in parts of eastern Oklahoma.

In 2008, thunderstorms moved through northeast Oklahoma and northwest Arkansas, producing 7 tornadoes. Luckily, no injuries were reported. Wind gusts greater than 80 mph occurred in Okfuskee, Muskogee, Mayes, Benton, and Carroll Counties. Throughout the path of the thunderstorms, penny size hail was common. All 7 tornadoes were produced in a path from Wagoner County, OK to Benton County, AR.

In 1920, 11.5 inches of snow fell in Tulsa on the 8th-9th. ^In 1962, much of southeast Oklahoma received heavy snow. Poteau received 6 inches and the rest of the area received 2 to 4 inches. Some ice also fell farther south.

In 1975, a tornado touched down on the south side of the USN Ammo plant in Pittsburg County at about 10:30PM. 5 mobile homes were destroyed in this twister's 12 mile intermittent path. Another tornado near Springdale, AR destroyed 3 mobile homes, injured 5 people, and damaged a house. Wind damage was also reported in Washington County, AR.

In 1977, heavy snow fell across east central Oklahoma and northwest Arkansas, with very cold temperatures from January 9-10. Over a foot of snow fell  in an area from southeast of Tulsa to Carroll County, AR, including 14 inches at Tahlequah, OK and Green Forest, AR. Low temperatures of -10 to -15 degrees were common in these areas on the morning of the 10th, including a low of-16 in Claremore, and -14 degrees in McAlester, their all-time record low.

In 1898, a violent tornado tore through Ft. Smith and Van Buren, AR killing 52 people in Ft. Smith and 3 others in Van Buren. The tornado touched down near the National Cemetery at about 11PM and did substantial damage there, then moved through downtown Ft. Smith, damaging much of the city's retail district and severely damaging the high school. A street sign from Ft. Smith was found 22 miles away. Sixteen of the deaths in Ft. Smith were in one residential block. The 55 total fatalities ties this for the deadliest tornado in Arkansas history.

In 2005, an intense line of severe thunderstorms moved across northwest Arkansas. Hardest hit were Centerton and Bentonville at around 6 pm that evening. More than two dozen homes sustained damage, and one person was injured by flying debris.

In 2007, a devastating ice storm occurred in eastern Oklahoma. Up to 3 inches of ice accumulated on trees and power lines in an area roughly 30 miles either side of a line from McAlester to Muskogee to Grove from January 12th-14th. 100,000 customers were without power to do the ice accumulation.

In 2005, floods occurred on the Neosho River near Commerce. The river rose above flood stage of 15 feet on the afternoon of January 13th. The river crested at 15.71 feet that night, and on the 14th it fell below flood stage.

In 1964, heavy snow fell across southeast Oklahoma. Boswell, OK in Choctaw County received 9 inches of snow. ^In 1986, January was a very dry month. Tulsa, Bartlesville, and several other counties reported no precipitation for the month.

In 1987, a winter storm affected northeast Oklahoma. Heavy snow of 6 to 10 inches fell generally north of I-44. ^In 2006, there were several reports of wildfires in northeast Oklahoma. One large fire in Tulsa County burned 250 acres in the Sperry area. Another fire in Creek County threatened the Never Sweat Ranch near Kellyville, and a fire in Wagoner County occurred near Elevator Road at the Verdigris River.

In 1996, severe thunderstorms moved across eastern Oklahoma, producing strong winds. Many structures were damaged and destroyed due to the wind near Schulter, OK. Chelsea, OK received strong enough winds to overturn a large travel trailer. Damage from thunderstorm winds was reported from Chelsea, Bearden, Wainwright, Council Hill, Gideon, McAlester, and Muldrow. Damage included destroyed or damaged homes, barns, businesses, automobiles, and trees. These thunderstorms moved into northwest Arkansas as well, producing 60 mph winds in Siloam Springs and Bentonville.

In 1930, Watts, OK reported an overnight low temperature of -27 degrees, which tied the all-time lowest temperature in Oklahoma at that time (the record was broken at Nowata on 2/10/2011). 1930 was the coldest January in the 20th century in Oklahoma. ^In 1995, heavy snow fell in northeast Oklahoma and northwest Arkansas. 4 to 8 inches of snow were common in several counties. Bluejacket, OK in Craig County received 14 inches.
In 1984, northeast Oklahoma experienced a cold snap from January 19th-22nd. Claremore dropped all the way to -20 degrees, while Vinita hit -17 degrees and Miami bottomed out at -15 degrees.

In 1985, record cold temperatures occurred in northeast Oklahoma and northwest Arkansas. Fayetteville, AR dropped to -12 degrees, while Pawhuska, OK and Claremore, OK reached -6 degrees. Fort Smith, AR reported wind chills near -25 degrees.

In 1933, a tornado touched down in Adair, OK in Mayes County. 5 people were injured by the twister. ^In 1999, three rounds of severe thunderstorms moved across west-central Arkansas and southeast Oklahoma. The worst storm in Oklahoma was the first round that began in Pushmataha County and moved northeast. The storm produced golf ball size hail, causing damage to several structures and vehicles. The second storm in Arkansas produced golf ball and baseball size hail along with a brief tornado. ^In 2018, severe thunderstorms developed over southeast OK and western AR in the afternoon and early evening. Two EF-1  tornadoes were confirmed in west central AR near Huntington and near Cecil.

In 1957, a powerful F4 tornado touched down in Gans, OK. The tornado killed 10 people and injured at least 20. A railroad engineer reportedly blew his train whistle to try to wake up the town and alert them of the twister. Two F2 tornadoes were reported in Okfuskee and Haskell Counties. The twister in Haskell County caused significant damage in Hoyt, OK. ^In 1995, heavy snow fell across parts of eastern Oklahoma and western Arkansas. 4 to 7 inches of snow were common south of a line from Oilton to Chouteau and west of a line from Chouteau to Spiro. As much as 10 inches fell in Latimer Co, OK. 4 to 6 inches of snow were common in the southern half of Sebastian County, AR.

In 2002, severe thunderstorms produced 70 mph winds along Kerr Lake to the southwest of Sallisaw. Various objects were damaged, including a small garage blown off its foundation, a travel trailer blown over, a chicken house, and a porch which was blown off a house.
In 1940, the coolest high temperature for this day occurred in Tulsa at 15 degrees. The coolest low temperature for this day was -4 degrees in 1908.

In 1967, a pair of F2 tornadoes moved through Rogers, Mayes, Craig, and Ottawa Counties. 8 people were injured and the post office in Foyil, OK in Rogers County was destroyed. In addition, several homes and businesses were damaged in Afton, OK in Ottawa County, including a truck stop and 2 motels.

In 1994, severe thunderstorms developed in northeast Oklahoma, producing large hail. 1 foot of baseball size hail covered the ground southwest of Vinita, and nickel size hail was 6 inches deep a few miles west of Vinita. ^In 2009, an ice storm occurred in northwest Arkansas and parts of eastern Oklahoma, producing 1-2 inches of ice. 187,000 customers lost power in Arkansas and 28,000 homes and businesses lost power in Oklahoma.

In 2000, heavy snow fell across eastern Oklahoma. An upper level system with gulf moisture moving northeast into the Plains out of the desert southwest, along with cold air that settled in OK earlier in the week, allowing several inches of snow to accumulate. 7 to 9 inches were common south of I-44, with 17 inches of snow in Eufaula, OK and Okmulgee, OK and 10 inches in McAlester.

In 2010, a winter storm in eastern Oklahoma and northwest Arkansas produced several inches of snow. Northeast Oklahoma and northwest Arkansas received about 5 to 8 inches of snow. Southeast Oklahoma, from north of McAlester to Heavener received 2 to 4 inches of snow. The storm also produced ice, which accumulated between a quarter and three-quarters of an inch in parts of northeast OK and northwest AR .

In 2008, the Ft. Chaffee Fire occurred. The large fire was driven by wind gusts of 45-55 mph. It destroyed 150 World War II era buildings that were once part of the base, and injured one firefighter. State Highway 22 was closed for several hours. ^In 2013,  severe thunderstorms occurred during the late afternoon and evening across far eastern OK and northwest AR. The storms produced 3 short lived tornadoes, including an EF-2 twister that developed in extreme northeastern Sequoyah Co., OK and moved north of Natural Dam, AR (Crawford Co.) through mainly rural areas. Trees and power poles were snapped and one house had minor damage within the 9 mile long path. Other tornadoes touched down near Elkins, AR (Washington Co.), where 40 to 50 homes suffered minor damage, and near Rockhouse, AR (Madison Co.).

In 2002, an ice storm occurred in eastern Oklahoma from January 29th-30th. On the 29th, the storm started out as rain due to a slow moving upper level system moving east from the Rockies and a shallow cold air mass moving south into Oklahoma. Overnight, temperatures remained above freezing over most of the area, but temperatures fell below freezing in Nowata, Washington, Osage, and Pawnee Counties. As 2-3 inches of rain fell, power lines and trees received a thick layer of ice accumulation, but roads were not icy because of warm soil temperatures. Some 18,000 homes and businesses lost power.

In 2006, Tulsa and Fayetteville both recorded their warmest January on record. ^In 2008, heavy snow fell across eastern Oklahoma and northwest Arkansas due to an upper level system that organized over the Southern Rockies and moved across the Southern Plains. Snow fell throughout the day, sometimes at a rate of a few inches per hour, resulting in heavy snowfall north of I-40. The heaviest snow fell along the Kansas border, where about 1 foot accumulated. Another heavy band of snow fell across Benton, Madison, and Carroll Counties.

In 1979, frigid temperatures occurred in the area. Pawhuska reached -14 degrees, Miami, Bartlesville, and Claremore reached -11 degrees, Tulsa was -7 degrees, and Fayetteville was -6 degrees. ^In 2011, a crippling blizzard occurred in northeast Oklahoma. Total snowfall amounts of 10-15 inches were common, and some areas along and north of Highway 412 and I-44 received 18-21 inches. Snow drifts of 3-5 feet were common. A single storm record of 14 inches fell in Tulsa.

In 2005, heavy snow moved across northwest Arkansas and eastern Oklahoma due to an upper level system that began moving northeast out of the southern Rockies on February 1st. The precipitation began as rain in southeast OK and turned to snow by the morning of February 2nd. That morning, snow fell across a large area of northeast OK and northwest AR with temperatures near or below freezing. Far northwest AR received heavy snow of up to 5.5 inches. ^In 2014, a swath of heavy snow fell from east central Oklahoma through northwest Arkansas, along with some minor ice accumulation in southeast Oklahoma. The highest snow totals included 7 inches near Checotah, OK (McIntosh Co) and 6 inches at Warner (Muskogee Co) and near Lincoln (Washington Co, AR).
In 2011, bitter cold temperatures were felt over much of northeast Oklahoma and northwest Arkansas. Lows of -5 to -15 were common, with -18 degrees recorded in Miami, OK.

In 1996, record cold temperatures were recorded in northeast OK and northwest AR. Snow was already on the ground, and with arctic air coming into the area, temperatures fell to well below zero. Low temperatures included -19 degrees in Vinita, -16 degrees in Claremore and Bentonville, -15 degrees in Bartlesville, Pawhuska, and Ralston, -14 degrees in Gravette, Mannford, and Pryor, -12 degrees in Miami and Bristow, -11 degrees in Tulsa, and -9 degrees in Fayetteville.

In 1942, a strong tornado moved across the southern area of Green Forest, Arkansas in Carroll County. The railroad depot, warehouses, railroad storehouses, several homes, and a store were destroyed. The twister caused 10 injuries as well.

In 1942, a tornado moved south of Hodgen, Oklahoma in LeFlore County. 1 person was killed and 5 were injured. 3 homes were also destroyed. ^In 1999, thunderstorms developed and moved across southeast Oklahoma to northeast Arkansas, producing strong winds and some hail. Estimated 60 mph winds occurred in both states. Some flash flooding occurred as well, with some areas having a few feet of water across the roads.

In 1927, the Arkansas River was already at a high stream flow and when heavy rain occurred, the river flooded. This was the most significant flooding since 1833. The flood extended through the 19th, and destroyed 165,000 acres causing $4 million (in 1927 dollars) in damages.

In 1980, heavy snow fell in the area from February 8th-9th. Some of the heavier totals were 12 inches in Pawhuska,  9 inches in Nowata, 8.5 inches in Bartlesville, 8 inches in Eureka Springs and  7 inches in Fayetteville, . ^In 2011, a narrow band of very heavy snow fell across northeast Oklahoma and northwest Arkansas. As much as 18-25 inches fell from northern Osage County, OK to Madison County, AR. The NWS Cooperative Observer in Spavinaw, OK measured 27 inches of snow from the event, establishing a new Oklahoma state record for 24-hour snowfall. Combined with the blizzard from the 1st, some locations saw nearly four feet of snow in a little over a week.

In 2003, heavy snow fell across northwest Arkansas and northeast Oklahoma. The heaviest snow occurred in Benton County, AR, with Pea Ridge receiving 8 inches and Siloam Springs receiving 7 inches. The snow caused hazardous road conditions, and one fatality occurred from this. In Oklahoma, the heaviest amounts included 10 inches in Peggs, Wagoner, and Kansas, and 6 inches in the Tulsa area.

In 2009, severe thunderstorms moved across eastern Oklahoma. An F0 tornado hit 3 miles SSW of Pawnee, destroying a barn and damaging several homes. Thunderstorm winds of about 80 mph struck near Pawnee, overturning a mobile home and damaging another. Okesa in Osage County received softball size hail, damaging cars and roofs. ^In 2011, the Oklahoma state record for lowest temperature was recorded at -31 degrees in Nowata, Oklahoma.

In 1972, heavy snow fell generally north of I-44, with most of the area receiving 4-6 inches of snow. ^In 2008, thunderstorms developed ahead of an approaching upper level storm system and north of a warm front. Surface temperatures were already below freezing across northeast OK, so the precipitation from the storms resulted in freezing rain and ice. Many counties received one quarter to half an inch of ice.

In 1899, the temperature fell to -15 in Fort Smith, and -24 in Fayetteville, the lowest temperatures ever recorded at both locations. ^In 1962, record high temperatures occurred in Tulsa on the 12th and 13th, with 86 degrees and 84 degrees respectively. Forth Smith saw record highs of 86 and 85 on those two days, respectively.

In 1905, a record-breaking cold snap resulted in several record low temperatures during mid-month. Gravette, Arkansas dropped to -29 degrees, which remains the all-time record coldest temperature for the state of Arkansas. Vinita, Oklahoma reached -27 degrees, which was the all-time state record until 2011.

In 1995, freezing rain occurred in Sequoyah County, OK, resulting in hazardous road conditions. Some roads were temporarily closed due to ice accumulations, and over 75 traffic accidents were reported. ^In 2004, a strong upper level low moved across north Texas, causing snow to fall in southeast Oklahoma. Snowfall amounts were scattered with most areas receiving 2 to 3 inches, but local amounts up to 6 inches fell in Pushmataha Co.

In 1993, heavy snow fell across northeast and east-central Oklahoma and northwest Arkansas due to a strong upper level storm. Areas along and north of I-40 received 6 to 10 inches of snow, with 12 inches in Fayetteville. ^In 2003, severe thunderstorms produced large hail across parts of northeast Oklahoma. 2 miles east of Jenks in Tulsa County, Verdigris in Rogers County, and 3 miles south of Glenpool in Tulsa County received penny size hail. Nickel size hail fell in Pryor, Mayes County.

In 1967, heavy snow fell across northeast Oklahoma. 5 to 7 inches fell in Cherokee, Adair, and southern Delaware Counties. During the storm, visibility was less than 50 feet. ^In 2008, heavy rainfall led to some flooding across parts of eastern Oklahoma. Several roads in Pushmataha County were closed from the flooding, and several low water crossings around Jay were flooded. A man drowned when he tried to drive through one of these low water crossings. ^In 2015, a strong upper-level system brought a mix of freezing rain and sleet, which transitioned to all snow.  Parts of northeast OK and northwest AR saw 3 to 6 inches of snow, while other areas of northeast OK and northwest AR received 1 to 2 inches of sleet. Reports of freezing rain indicated only a glaze to around a tenth of an inch of ice accumulation occurred.

In 1961, a likely family of tornadoes traveled from south central Oklahoma northeast to Okmulgee County. 1 injury was reported on a farm near Pharaoh, OK in Okfuskee County. The damage path was 80 miles. ^In 2011, just one week after record breaking cold, temperatures warmed into the upper 70s and lower 80s across northeast Oklahoma, making a 90 to 110 degree temperature change in a week. Within one week, Nowata, OK had a 110 degree temperature change.

In 1989, a flash flood in Carroll County caused 1 fatality, and 2 to 4 feet of water covered the road. ^In 2006, a winter storm moved through the region from the 18th-20th. 4 to 5 inches of snow fell across northwest Arkansas by daybreak on the 18th. Madison County, AR was impacted by a mixture of freezing rain and snow. Other northwest Arkansas counties received at least an inch of sleet. The second round of precipitation moved through on the 19th, bringing at least an inch of sleet to eastern OK.

In 1921, a major winter storm dumped 8 to 18 inches of snow over most of eastern Oklahoma and western Arkansas. Fort Smith, AR set an all-time storm total snowfall record with 18.3 inches. A number of buildings suffered roof damage from the weight of the snow in Ft. Smith and Van Buren. ^In 1994, severe thunderstorms developed in northeast Oklahoma, producing damaging winds of 70-75 mph. Winds near Kellyville overturned a mobile home and destroyed an airplane hangar and a barn. Damaging winds were also reported in Vinita and Bristow.

In 1976, a tornado hit northeast of Sallisaw, OK in Sequoyah County, damaging a few farm houses. ^In 1997, a cluster of severe thunderstorms moved from extreme eastern Oklahoma to northwest Arkansas, producing very strong winds and a few tornadoes. 70 mph winds and a brief tornado were reported in LeFlore County, OK. 90 mph winds were estimated in Pocola where a weak tornado hit. 70 mph winds were also reported in Sebastian County, AR, and in Fort Smith an 18-wheeler was blown over. Wind damage was widespread over the area.

In 1925, a tornado touched down in the west side of Henryetta, OK in Okmulgee County. About a dozen homes were damaged and there were 2 injuries. ^In 1971, one of the worst winter storms in OK history for the northwest portion of the state occurred, with 36 inches of snow in Buffalo, OK. As for northeast OK, 5 inches fell in Bartlesville and Foraker, 6 inches in Pawhuska, 7 inches in Ralston, Burbank, and Pawnee, and 2-3 inches fell in Tulsa.

In 1985, an F1 tornado touched down near Oolagah, OK, damaging a house. Floods were also a problem with this storm, and 1 fatality occurred in Sapulpa. Miami and Skiatook also received flooding. The Neosho River near Commerce was 13 feet above flood stage by the 25th, and up to 7 feet of water flooded some homes in Miami. ^In 1988, gusts of 52 mph were measured in Fort Smith and 44 mph in Fayetteville. Scattered power outages and several wildfires occurred from the strong wind. ^In 1996, high temperature records occurred in Tulsa at 90 degrees, McAlester at 92 degrees, Bartlesville at 91 degrees, and Fayetteville at 87 degrees. All of these broke or tied all-time record highs for February.

In 1985, thunderstorms moved through northwest Arkansas and produced heavy rainfall. 6.55 inches of rain fell in Combs (Madison County), and street flooding occurred in Fort Smith and Van Buren. The previous day brought severe flooding to northeast Oklahoma. ^In 2003, heavy snowfall of 10 to 18 inches fell in northeast Oklahoma near the Kansas border. 4 to 8 inches were common in the Tulsa area eastward and into northwest Arkansas. The winter storm also brought gusty winds which caused snow blowing and drifting, leading to many school closings and travel problems.

In 1935, tornadoes struck from northeast Oklahoma into Kansas and Missouri. A dozen homes were destroyed, 1 person was killed, and 19 people were hospitalized due to a twister that hit the mining community of Douthat, just south of Pitcher, OK.  Another town hit was the community of Hockerville, just south of the Kansas border. About 40 people were injured in the two twisters. ^In 2003, heavy snow across southeast Oklahoma brought 10 inches to Pushmataha County and 8 inches at Octavia in LeFlore County. Other areas received 2 to 4 inches of snow.

In 1993, an ice storm knocked out electricity to over 50,000 homes in the Arkansas River valley. ^In 2000, an F1 tornado touched down briefly one mile southeast of Tulsa International Airport, near the corner of Pine and Garnett. Damages included some equipment at a farm implement dealership and a parked car that was thrown on top of another parked car. The tornado also blew down eight power poles.

In 2003, freezing drizzle fell across eastern Oklahoma throughout the morning. Many areas closed school due to icy roads, and the hardest hit areas were Okfuskee and Okmulgee Counties near the intersection of I-40 and Highway 75. About 20 accidents were reported on I-40 in Okfuskee County, and near Henryetta in Okmulgee County a few tractor trailer rigs jackknifed climbing a hill on I-40. Due to the accidents, the highway closed for a few hours. Light freezing drizzle fell in northwest Arkansas as well. Several accidents occurred along Highway 71 near the Washington-Crawford border. ^In 2018, several rounds of heavy rain from the 20th-26th resulted in widespread totals of 5-8 inches south of I-44, with some amounts near 10 inches in SE OK. One fatality occurred in Adair Co, OK on the 21st, and moderate flooding occurred along the Illinois and Poeau Rivers.

In 1918, a mother and child were killed in a tornado near Fairfax, OK in Osage County as they ran to a storm cellar. ^In 1984, heavy snow fell across northwest Arkansas. The heaviest snow was measured north of Fort Smith, Heber Springs, and Batesville, including totals of 15 inches in Marble and 12 inches in Fayetteville. Heavy wet snow damaged trees, power lines/poles, and poultry houses. Lightning also caused a fire in Gravette and damaged a home. ^In 2015, moderate to heavy bands of snow affected all of eastern OK and northwest AR on the 27th and 28th.  While most locations received 2 to 4 inches, a narrow mesoscale very heavy snow band dumped 5 to 8 inches to the north and northwest of Tulsa, including much of Osage and Pawnee Counties. 7 to 8 inches of snow was reported in Barnsdall, Skiatook, and Hominy (Osage County).

In 1955, a tornado hit near Lake McAlester in Pittsburg County, OK, unroofing a house and destroying a bath house, cabin, and several trailers. The twister damaged several other buildings along the lake as well. ^In 2006, eastern Oklahoma and west-central Arkansas were in severe to exceptional drought conditions. 3 month (Dec-Feb) precipitation totals were between 25 and 50 percent of normal across northeast and east central Oklahoma, making it the driest winter since 1921.

In 1960, February was a cold and snowy month over much of the area. A series of storms mainly during the second half of the month brought monthly snowfall totals of 13.5 inches in Fayetteville, 11.5 inches in Ft. Smith and 11 inches in Webbers Falls. ^In 2017, Fort Smith and Fayetteville had their warmest February on record, while Tulsa had its 2nd warmest. For the winter of 2016-17, Tulsa and Fayetteville recorded their 2nd warmest winter, while Fort Smith saw its 3rd warmest.

In 1988, severe thunderstorms moved through northeast Oklahoma, causing wind damage near Claremore. There were also several reports of up to golf ball size hail. ^In 1997, isolated severe thunderstorms developed in southeast Oklahoma, producing nickel and dime size hail in the vicinity of Heavener. Storms later developed in northwest Arkansas, producing dime size hail near Huntsville, Greenwood, and Jenny Lind.

In 1971, a winter storm brought several inches of snow and near zero visibility to eastern Oklahoma from March 2nd-3rd. Towards the south, sleet and freezing rain fell. Checotah received 5 inches of snow, McAlester 4 inches, Hanna 6 inches, Stilwell 5.3 inches, and Fayetteville 3 inches. ^In 2002, heavy snow fell across eastern Oklahoma and northwest Arkansas as an arctic cold front moved across the region. Up to 9 inches of snow fell in Vinita, OK.

In 1985, severe thunderstorms moved across eastern Oklahoma. A school and bank were damaged in Bartlesville, and the police department flooded, resulting in $100,000 in damages. High winds in Shamrock damaged a mobile home, destroyed a barn, and injured one person. Other wind damage was found in Bristow, Sand Springs, Sperry, Stilwell, and Eufaula. ^In 2008, a winter storm occurred in eastern OK during the evening of the 3rd. The snowfall accumulated up to 4-8 inches. During the morning of the 3rd, heavy rain fell across northwest Arkansas, causing flash flooding. The rain changed to snow in that evening and up to 4-6 inches fell.

In 1989, a winter storm moved across eastern Oklahoma and northwest Arkansas. In Oklahoma, freezing rain and sleet turned to snow the afternoon of the 4th with near blizzard conditions in southeast OK on the 5th. 10-15 inches of snow fell along and north of I-40 with drifts up to 3-6 feet in some areas. Wind chills were 20-30 degrees below.  Some 2.4 million chickens were killed, resulting in $20 million in damages to farms. In northwest Arkansas, 2-3 inches of freezing rain and drizzle fell on the 4th, followed by up to 12 inches of snow in Benton County. 1 million chickens were killed as weight of snow collapsed the chicken houses. ^In 2004, heavy thunderstorm rains caused extensive flash flooding in areas of northeast Oklahoma. Bartlesville received 4.54 inches of rain. ^In 2015, A strong cold front moved through the region, bringing winter weather to all of eastern OK and northwest AR.  Rain transitioned briefly to freezing rain and sleet before finally becoming snow.  Sleet and snowfall totals ranged from a trace to 5 inches, with the majority of the area getting 1 to 2 inches.  Highest totals occurred across Cherokee, Adair, Delaware, Crawford, Franklin, Madison, and Carroll County, with 5 inches of sleet and snow reported 4 miles north of Pettigrew, AR (Madison Co.).

In 1999, severe thunderstorms developed in northwest Arkansas due to an approaching cold front and an upper level disturbance. The largest storm developed in Sequoyah County, OK and strengthened as it moved into Arkansas. The storm produced up to softball size hail in Alma, AR, along with a brief tornado.

In 1967, heavy snow fell across eastern Oklahoma. Much of the area received 3 to 6 inches of snow, but some areas had more. Near Checotah, Sallisaw, Webbers Falls, and Tahlequah, 5 to 6 inches fell. The snow remained on the ground for 2 to 3 days.

In 2008, heavy snow fell in northwest Arkansas due to a strong upper level storm system that traveled across from western and northern Texas. A band of heavy snow fell east of Berryville to Fort Smith to Antlers. 10 to 20 inches fell across southern LeFlore County, OK and southern Sebastian County, AR.

In 1994, heavy snow fell in northeast and east-central Oklahoma. Snowfall amounts ranged from 4 inches all the way up to 18 inches, as thunderstorms accompanied the snow. The heaviest snow amounts were located in southern Osage, Pawnee, northern Creek, Tulsa, Wagoner, and eastern Delaware Counties. Pawnee received 15 inches, but unofficial amounts of 18 inches were measured in Delaware County. The 12.9 inches of snow that fell at Tulsa International Airport was, at the time, an all-time record for daily snowfall. ^In 1999, multiple tornadoes touched down in northeast OK. Thunderstorms produced a twister in Broken Arrow (Tulsa County) and 6 tornadoes in Mcintosh County. 2 of the 6 tornadoes in Mcintosh County were F2's.

In 1964, a winter storm produced heavy snowfall and sleet over eastern Oklahoma. 5 to 9 inches of snow fell in Delaware, Adair, Cherokee, Wagoner, Muskogee, and Sequoyah Counties. The heaviest total was 12 inches in Tahlequah.

In 1974, severe thunderstorms moved through northwest Arkansas, producing large hail. Up to softball size hail fell in Uniontown and Cedarville in Crawford County. Damages included broken windows and damaged roofs.

In 1968, a late winter storm dumped from 4 to 10 inches of snow over much of northeast Oklahoma and northwest Arkansas. As much as 15 inches fell in Berryville, AR, with 14 inches in Miami, OK, 12.5 inches in Fayetteville, 10 inches in the Tulsa area and 4 inches in Ft. Smith. ^In 2011, wildfires broke out due to southerly winds of 20-30 mph, relative humidity below 20%, temperatures in the lower to middle 70s, and dormant vegetation. More than 40 wildfires were reported across eastern Oklahoma, and 8600 acres were burned. 1600 acres were burned in Pushmataha County, 1500 acres were burned in Latimer County, and 1500 acres were burned in LeFlore County. Luckily, no homes were destroyed.

In 1961, tornadoes developed in northwest Arkansas. One of the tornadoes destroyed several homes and farm buildings in Franklin County, and there were 4 injuries. Another twister hit Carroll County at Panorama Point, destroying a drive-in cafe, a house, and several other buildings. 14 injuries were reported, and 5 cars were overturned. ^In 2006, a tornado outbreak occurred in northeast Oklahoma and northwest Arkansas. 20 people were injured and over 500 homes were damaged in Delaware County, OK and Benton County, AR.

In 1922, a tornado hit the mining town of Gowan, OK in Latimer County. 10 people were killed, 50 were injured, and 19 homes were leveled. ^In 1990, severe thunderstorms developed and were part of a large tornado outbreak in the Plains (mainly west-central OK, KS, and NE). An F2 tornado hit 6 miles east of Slick, OK, destroying barns and causing $75,000 in damages. The storms also produced large hail, with teacup/large apple size hail near Beggs. Fort Gibson, Muskogee, and Grand Lake received wind damage the next morning.

In 1999, heavy snow fell in northeast Oklahoma and northwest Arkansas due to a powerful upper level system that moved eastward along the Red River Valley. This storm was one of the most significant winter storms on record. Some areas, like Creek County, experienced a snow-burst that was associated with thunder and lightning, causing very high amounts of snow. As much as 16 inches of snow fell near Eureka Springs, AR, with 14 inches in Bristow, OK.

In 1919, a tornado outbreak from Oklahoma to Iowa occurred. 2 people were killed and 25 were injured in Porter, OK (Wagoner County) where about 25 homes were destroyed. Another strong tornado destroyed 6 homes and damaged several others in the Stanley and Crum Creek communities in Pushmataha County, OK. ^In 1982, multiple tornadoes touched down in northeast Oklahoma. An F3 tornado in Bartlesville caused extensive damage. 57 people were injured when the twister hit downtown. Several structures including homes and churches were damaged and destroyed. An F2 tornado hit Pawhuska, while other F2s hit Nowata County and Lenapah. F1 tornadoes hit Wynona, Copan and Stigler.

In 1965, a tornado damaged a farm house and destroyed 3 barns and 2 outbuildings near Pawhuska. 20 boat houses and a dock was also damaged at Lake Bluestem. ^In 1970, heavy snow fell in northeast Oklahoma and northwest Arkansas. In Oklahoma, snowfall amounts included: 21 inches in Nowata, 20 inches in Bartlesville, 18 inches in Vinita, 16 inches in Claremore, 13 inches in Pawhuska and 9 inches in Tulsa. In Arkansas, heaviest amounts were 14 inches in Gravette and 12 inches in Eureka Springs.

In 1988, heavy snow fell across northwest Arkansas, bringing up to 14 inches to the area, especially in high elevations. 14 inches of snow fell in Huntsville in Madison County, while 10 inches were reported near Eureka Springs. ^In 2004, severe thunderstorms moved across northeast Oklahoma and northwest Arkansas. There were numerous reports of large hail, of up to hen egg/lime size hail. There were also some reports of wind damage.

In 1927, the Green Forest, AR tornado occurred. The violent twister killed 24 people and injured 110. The tornado was up to a mile wide, and destroyed most of the southern half of town. 200 homes were damaged or destroyed, and at least 10 homes were swept away, killing entire families. Another tornado killed 1 person and injured 5 in Burbank, OK in Osage County. ^In 1971, strong gusty winds caused the second severe dust storm in a week, lowering visibility to 1-2 miles in a large area. Wildfires also broke out, burning over 50,000 acres of timber. ^In 2008, flash flooding occurred northeast Oklahoma and northwest Arkansas due to heavy thunderstorm rains. Many roads were flooded and some homes were evacuated.

In 1969, wildfires broke out in northeast Oklahoma, burning several structures near Grand Lake. ^In 2002, heavy rain fell from the evening of the 18th to the morning of the 20th. During this event, Antlers, OK received 7.49 inches of rain, Fort Smith received 5.32 inches, Midland, AR received 6.23, Mountainburg, AR 6.41 . The result of the rain was widespread flash flooding , covering several roads with water across southeast Oklahoma and west-central Arkansas.

In 1924, heavy snow fell in northeast Oklahoma. Tulsa received 11.5 inches of snow, pushing the March total to 19.7 inches, the all-time snowfall record for the month of March in Tulsa. ^In 2010, heavy snow fell across much of eastern Oklahoma and northwest Arkansas. Some areas of far eastern Oklahoma and parts of northwest Arkansas received more than 10 inches of snow, and parts of Washington County, AR received 15 inches. The 7.5 inches in Fort Smith established new records for daily, storm total, and monthly totals for March.

In 2008, the Illinois River near Watts rose above its flood stage of 13 feet on March 19th. The river crested at 24.73 feet before falling back below flood stage on the 20th. This crest level was classified at a major flood category and tied for 3rd highest crest level for the site. The Illinois River near Tahlequah and the Poteau River near Panama also rose above their flood levels. River flooding occurred until March 24th, and nearly 20,000 acres of farmland were flooded.

In 1966, a strong cold front moved though the area with very strong wind gusts. Gusts of 65 mph were measured in McAlester, and wildfires broke out in Osage, Washington, Nowata, and Creek Counties, burning 30,000 acres. ^In 1974, a late season cold snap occurred. Low temperatures were in the teens to low 20s from the 21st to 25th. Light snow fell on the 21st, and freezing drizzle fell in northeast Oklahoma on the 22nd and 23rd. Some damage to peach and apple crops was reported. Temperatures warmed into the low to mid 90s many areas within a week.

In 1990, a winter storm moved across northeast Oklahoma, producing sleet and freezing rain. Due to ice accumulation, Tulsa had widespread power outages. ^In 1999, severe thunderstorms formed along a strong cold front in northeast Oklahoma. The storms developed in Payne County and moved east, producing up to golf ball size hail in Creek County. Storms weakened as the front moved south, and only produced penny to quarter size hail. ^In 2016, a strong (EF-2) tornado developed in extreme southeastern Adair County and moved into Crawford County. The tornado moved roughly along Highway 59 where it snapped or uprooted numerous trees and destroyed a mobile home, severely injuring two people. The tornado caused 2 other minor injuries in southwestern Washington County, where a mobile home was rolled off its footings.

In 1914, violent sandstorms occurred in western Oklahoma on March 18th and 24th. ^In 1997, severe thunderstorms moved across northeast Oklahoma from late evening on the 24th to the early morning of the 25th, producing strong winds. 70 mph winds caused damage in Hominy, and strong wind in Okmulgee blew the roofs off several homes and businesses. 75 mph winds were measured near Collinsville and 59 to 70 mph winds were measured across various areas in northeast Oklahoma.

In 1948, a tornado outbreak occurred in central and eastern Oklahoma into western Arkansas. This event is famous for being the first successful forecast of a tornado which hit Tinker Air Force base east of Oklahoma City. Later that evening, a large tornado moved from Hughes County into McIntosh County, destroying at least 5 farms and killing 3 people. 7 were killed in Hughes County. Another likely family of tornadoes traveled 85 miles from McIntosh County north of Eufaula to Mountainburg, AR in Crawford County. Several other people were killed or injured in this destructive path. ^In 2015, six tornadoes occurred from west of Tulsa into northwest Arkansas. A strong EF-2 tornado struck west of Sand Springs, OK (Tulsa Co), where 1 person was killed and 30 others injured. Another weak tornado touched down less than a mile from  the NWS office in Tulsa, with wind damage to the office building housing the NWS and to several staff member vehicles. In addition to the severe weather, heavy rains caused flooding across northeast OK and northwest AR. 3 fatalities occurred in the flooding, including one near Eureka Springs, AR (Carroll Co) and 2 near Webbers Falls, OK (Muskogee Co).

In 1949, a strong tornado hit the town of Crowder, OK in Pittsburg County, killing 2 people and injuring 25. 45 homes and 13 businesses were damaged or destroyed. Another tornado caused damage from near Christie, OK in Adair County to Tontitown, AR in Washington County. ^In 1976, a pair of violent tornadoes hit Latimer and LeFlore Counties in OK. The first was an F4 and the second was a possible F5. Several homes were damaged or destroyed, and 3 people were killed.

In 1998, a powerful spring storm moved from Kansas and Missouri to northeast Oklahoma and northwest Arkansas. Wind gusts of 50 to 60 mph were common across the region. Stilwell in Adair County, OK reported a gust of 75 mph. Several homes and power lines/poles were damaged from the strong winds. ^In 2000, Tulsa county received tennis ball sized hail. Cars and houses were damaged and the total storm damage was $2 million.
In 1938, a tornado hit Wilburton, OK, damaging over 200 homes. 7 students at Eastern Oklahoma College were also injured by flying glass in the library and dorm.

In 2009, heavy snow fell across northeast Oklahoma due to a strong upper level low pressure system that traveled from northwestern Texas across southeastern Oklahoma into northwestern Arkansas. Precipitation began as rain, but changed to snow on the 28th and continued through the night. Some areas received very heavy snowfall, and 4 to 6 inches was widespread through northeastern Oklahoma.  A persistent band of convective snow developed near and north of the Tulsa area, with up to ten inches falling across northern Creek, southeastern Pawnee, and southeastern Osage Counties.

In 1938, a tornado outbreak impacted a large area from Oklahoma to Illinois. The outbreak began in northeast Oklahoma, and a family of tornadoes moved through Osage, Washington, and Nowata Counties while students were in school. The tornadoes damaged a school near Avant, OK in Osage County and partially collapsed a school in Washington County, injuring 4 students. A large tornado near Hollow, OK in Craig County injured 5 people and destroyed several structures, and the same twister moved on to kill 10 people in Columbus, KS. ^In 1998, an F1 tornado and thunderstorm winds caused damage in Gravette, AR. ^In 2016, two strong (EF-2) tornadoes tracked across the northern portions of the Tulsa metro area. The first damaged more than 300 homes, 13 churches and businesses and injured 7 people in north Tulsa. Several large, metal-framed, industrial buildings were significantly damaged north-northeast of Tulsa International Airport. A second EF-2 tornado tracked just south of Claremore, damaging several homes near Highway 88. Total damage was estimated to be just under 4 million dollars.

In 1924, heavy snow impacted most of eastern Oklahoma throughout the month. Eufaula had the most snow of the month with 21 inches. ^In 1974, northeast Oklahoma and northwest Arkansas experienced record high temperatures. Tulsa and Okmulgee both hit 96 degrees, while Fort Smith, Bartlesville, McAlester, and Pawhuska reached 94 degrees. Fayetteville reached 89 degrees, establishing  a monthly record.

In 1983, non-thunderstorm winds tore off a roof of a school in Wann, OK in Washington County. ^In 2006, a tornado developed near the Tulsa International Airport along the leading edge of a thunderstorm. The tornado injured 7 people in a hotel, overturned an SUV at the airport, and damaged 75 cars and other structures. Strong thunderstorm winds also damaged 4 airplanes at the airport. ^In 2018, the month of April 2018 was the record coldest in Fayetteville, AR, the 2nd coldest at Tulsa and the 3rd coldest at Fort Smith. There were no confirmed tornadoes in Oklahoma in 2018 through April for the first time in recorded history.

In 1982, An F5 tornado went through Choctaw and McCurtain counties. The tornado path was 53 miles long and caused over $7 million of property damage. An F2 tornado hit near Claremore, damaging  school. Another F2 hit near Pryor, and an F3 tornado touched down near Boswell/Soper in Choctaw County. Strong non-thunderstorm winds also occurred behind the dry line in northeast OK causing significant damage to boats and docks at Keystone Lake. One injury each was reported in Tulsa, Glenpool, and Miami. ^In 2015, A tornado touched down north of I-44 in Craig County around 10 pm and moved east-southeast, eventually crossing I-44 and blowing over two tractor trailers. One of the drivers was injured. Significant damage also occurred near Afton, OK (Ottawa Co).

In 1956, several tornadoes struck Oklahoma and Kansas from the afternoon of the 2nd to the early morning of the 3rd. An F4 tornado passed through Drumright, OK in Creek County, destroying 63 homes and damaging at least 200 others in a 40-block section of town. 5 people were killed and dozens were injured. A church was destroyed, but the Bible was found undisturbed. After midnight, a possible F4 tornado touched down near Narcissa, OK in Ottawa County and moved through Miami, OK and Quapaw, OK. 46 people were injured in Miami.

In 1969, a tornado hit Monkey Island on Grand Lake, destroying 7 boats, while another tornado hit Arrowhead Lodge on Eufaula Lake. ^In 1985, severe thunderstorms developed in the late evening of the 4th and lasted until the early morning of the 5th. Wind damage was reported in Miami, Big Cabin, Tulsa, Broken Arrow, Sapulpa, Pryor, and Jay. 2 mobile homes were overturned near Claremore and a house was damaged. Muskogee received $100,000 in damages and a school was severely damaged in Westville.

In 1947, a tornado touched down south of Wister, OK in LeFlore County and moved northeast to Sebastian County, AR. 4 people were killed in one home in the Glendale farm community south of Wister and about 30 other homes were damaged or destroyed in OK. ^In 2005, Jenks in Tulsa county was hit by a supercell, producing up to 3-inch diameter hail. Golf ball size hail was common in the area and there was much damage to homes, cars, and businesses.

In 1902, a tornado touched down in Hugo, OK in Choctaw County at about 9pm. The tornado caused significant damage in the town's main business district, and a dozen buildings under construction were destroyed.

In 1980, a tornado struck the north side of Poteau, damaging a shopping center and several houses. Another tornado hit near Dewey, OK in Osage County destroying some farm buildings. A tornado with a 22-mile path tracked from near Pensacola in Mayes County to south Ottawa County. Several homes and structures were damaged or destroyed along its path. Another tornado hit just north of Jay, OK. ^In 1986, severe thunderstorms producing 70 mph winds and an F2 tornado 4 miles northwest of Adair, OK caused extensive damage. Flooding in Lowell, AR cost $400,000 in damages, and the tornado in Adair, OK caused $200,000 in damages. ^In 2018, light snow fell across NE OK and NW AR, with amounts generally an inch or less. This was only the 4th time since 1900 that measurable snow  occurred in Tulsa in April.

In 1965, a tornado hit the northeast side of Muskogee in the Muskogee Compress District. Additional damage was reported 1.5 miles northeast. ^In 2002, heavy rainfall of 4 to 6 inches caused significant flooding of roads in southeast Oklahoma and northwest Arkansas from the late afternoon of the 7th to the early morning of the 8th. Part of St. Paul, AR was evacuated because of the flooding of low lying areas. Luckily, no homes were flooded.

In 2007, an arctic high pressure system brought unseasonably cold temperatures from the 4th to the 9th. Overnight temperatures dropped down to the 30s over a large area on the 4th. Northwest Arkansas reached freezing temperatures for 5 mornings and several mornings reached temperatures in the teens and lower 20s. Fruit crops were severely damaged. ^In 2009, an F2 tornado hit near Page, OK in LeFlore County, injuring 4 people. Maximum winds were estimated to be 120-130 mph.

In 1979, the Red River Valley Tornado Outbreak occurred. Most notably, a devastating tornado touched down in Wichita Falls, TX and killed 42 people. Storms continued into eastern Oklahoma and northwest Arkansas late that night. A weak tornado touched down in Muskogee Co after midnight, and an F2 tornado struck near Prairie Grove, AR in Washington Co the next morning. ^In 2007, severe thunderstorms moved across eastern OK, producing strong winds. Powerful thunderstorm winds destroyed two mobile homes in Pittsburg, OK and damaged several homes. Wind speeds were estimated at 85 to 95 mph based on the storm damage. ^In 2008, severe thunderstorms produced an F2 tornado near Stilwell in Adair County, OK that moved into Washington County, AR. The tornado destroyed a mobile home and a barn, rolled a vehicle, and caused tree damage.

In 1943, a tornado hit the northeast edge of Poteau, OK in the mid afternoon. The twister destroyed or damaged 20 homes in the Lakeview section. There was one fatality and other 12 injuries. ^In 2001, severe thunderstorms moved across eastern Oklahoma and northwest Arkansas. Thunderstorm winds in Choctaw County, OK destroyed 3 mobile homes, and roofs were blown off in Muskogee. An F1 tornado developed near Stigler and traveled 3 miles, tearing off a roof and a porch from a house and 6 barns were destroyed. Strong winds were common in eastern Oklahoma/northwest Arkansas.

In 1911, a tornado outbreak occurred in eastern Oklahoma and west central Arkansas. 5 people were killed in the community of Bigheart (now Barnsdall, OK in Osage County). Most of the homes in the community and a new school were destroyed. 4 other people were killed in McIntosh County, OK and Crawford County, AR (2 each). 8 significant tornadoes were documented. ^In 1945, one of eastern Oklahoma's worst tornado outbreaks occurred, with 104 fatalities altogether. Antlers, OK in Pushmataha County experienced Oklahoma's 4th deadliest tornado in history. The F5 twister killed 69 people and injured over 350. At least 1000 buildings were damaged or destroyed. In 1945 dollars, the damage cost was $1.5 million. Other deadly tornadoes moved over Muskogee, where 13 were killed and over 200 injured, near the Boggy community in Latimer Co (3 killed), near Roland in Sequoyah Co (7 killed), near Hulbert in Cherokee Co (4 killed), and near Japton (1 killed) and Marble (7 members of one family killed) in Crawford County, AR. News of this outbreak was overshadowed by a more significant national news story...the passing of President Franklin D. Roosevelt.

In 1986, an F2 tornado hit Broken Arrow, Oklahoma. 2 people were injured and damage was about $60,000. Wind damage also occurred in Rogers County, where a mobile home was overturned and 1 person was injured. Morris, OK experienced 95 mph wind gusts. ^In 1987, severe thunderstorms produced an F1 tornado in Lavaca, AR (Sebastian County). 3 houses were damaged and 1 was destroyed. Wind damage also occurred at the Crawford County Fairgrounds in Mulberry, and in Branch and Green Forest, AR. ^In 2018 Severe thunderstorms developed over eastern OK during the early afternoon. These storms organized into a line as they approached western AR and produced damaging wind gusts across the area through early evening as well as a weak tornado east of Lavaca, AR. Scattered storms formed over far eastern OK ahead of the line and moved across portions of western AR during the mid afternoon. One of these storms produced a strong tornado (EF-2) in Crawford County that injured four people and caused considerable damage near and around the town of Mountainburg.

In 1883, a tornado hit the small community of White Oak, AR in Franklin County. The twister nearly destroyed the community, and there were 3 fatalities and 10 other injuries. ^In 1927, heavy rainfall left several parts of eastern Oklahoma flooded. The town of Blaine along the Arkansas River was stranded when a bridge washed away, and a mining disaster in Henryetta was avoided when a veteran miner led the men working to safety from the incoming flood waters. ^In 2011, 25 tornadoes were reported in the NWS Tulsa's forecast area in a single day...a record for one day. A total of 8 people were injured.

In 1933, One of the latest significant snowstorms to hit northwest Arkansas dumped 8.6 inches of snow in Fayetteville, with unofficial reports up to 15 inches, and around 9 inches at Eureka Springs. The heavy wet snow knocked down telegraph lines and many tree limbs. Ft. Smith saw 0.7 inches of snow, making that the latest measurable snow on record there. ^In 2001, severe thunderstorms in northwest Arkansas produced 99 mph winds. 3 hangars and a few planes were seriously damaged at the Northwest Arkansas Regional Airport around 1am.

In 1990, severe thunderstorms produced golf ball size hail in Bentonville, Arkansas. The storm caused widespread roof and window damage. Flash flooding also occurred in Washington County, AR. There was also wind damage in Tahlequah and Kinta, OK. ^In 1994, major river flooding occurred across northeast Oklahoma from April 10th to 16th. 2 to 5 inches of rain were common, with some areas like Osage County receiving 7 inches. The high amount of runoff caused most rivers and streams in the area to flood. The Neosho River at Commerce significantly flooded, affecting Miami, OK.

In 1995, severe thunderstorms moved across eastern Oklahoma and northwest Arkansas. The storms produced 8 tornadoes, large hail, and strong thunderstorm winds. ^In 2013, severe weather and flooding occurred across northeast OK and northwest AR when a line of severe thunderstorms late in the evening of the 17th into the early morning of the 18th. This line of thunderstorms evolved into a bow echo and moved swiftly across northeast OK and northwest AR, producing wind damage, large hail, and several brief tornadoes.  Tornado damage was reported in Broken Arrow, Inola, Salina, Spavinaw, and Butler (near Grove) in northeast OK. Flooding was widespread across east-central OK and far northwest AR, where rainfall amounts were 3 to 5 inches with isolated reports of up to 7 inches.  Several State Highways were impassible due to high water, as well as many smaller city, town, and county roads.

In 1880, tornadoes hit northwest Arkansas. A long track tornado killed one person in Skulleyville, Indian Territory (Sequoyah Co), 2 more south of Fort Smith and one in Franklin County, AR. Another tornado killed 2 in Fayetteville. ^In 1927, a tornado crossed the Red River after hitting in Arthur City, TX. 10 people were killed and around 60 were injured in Choctaw County, OK. An entire family of 6 was killed on the Kiamichi River.

In 1968, a violent F4 tornado touched down in Greenwood, AR around 3:15 pm, killing 14 people and damaging or destroying about 400 homes and 69 businesses as the twister hit downtown. The death toll could have been much higher as the High School was hit not long after school had let out for the day. ^In 1981, a tornado killed 5 people and injured 49 in Bixby, OK. Another tornado hit 66th and Yale in Tulsa causing $100 million in damages. Tornadoes also hit near Kiefer, Mounds, and Broken Arrow. ^In 2003, a tornado in Washington County, AR produced F2 damage and damaged several structures. 5 other tornadoes hit eastern Oklahoma that day.

In 1984, severe thunderstorms caused extensive wind damage in Fort Smith, AR to the airport, a mobile home dealership, and other structures. Gusts of 76 mph occurred in Fort Smith. Wind damage also occurred nearby in Kibler, Alma and Mulberry. Pocola, OK in LeFlore County received $300,000 in damages.

In 1996, a strong F3 tornado touched down in Fort Smith shortly after 11 pm, killing 2 people and injuring 89.  Hundreds of homes were destroyed, or damaged, over a thousand homes had minor damage, and at least 90 businesses were damaged or destroyed along a 10-mile path in Sebastian and Crawford counties by the twister. Several brick buildings in downtown Fort Smith were either damaged or destroyed. Two other tornadoes touched down in northwest Arkansas, including another strong tornado that killed 2 in St. Paul. 7 other tornadoes were reported in eastern Oklahoma.

In 2004, an active week of severe thunderstorms occurred from the 20th to 24th, with daily rounds of strong winds, torrential rain, and a few tornadoes. An F1 tornado touched down near Mazie, OK on the 22nd and traveled to east of Murphy. Fayetteville and Prairie Grove received about 7 inches of rain, which caused flash flooding in the area. Flash flooding caused $6 million in damages to roads, and a train track near Greenland was washed out.

In 1908, heavy rain and hail occurred in Muskogee, OK. The rainfall resulted in loss of street car service, broken storm sewers, and extensive flooding within the city. Lightning caused problems in the oil fields to the tanks and derricks, especially in Kiefer and Sapulpa. At least 15 large tanks of oil were destroyed along with 8-10 derricks.

In 1904, a tornado killed 4 people in Fairland, OK (Ottawa County) and 1 in Wyandotte. Another tornado killed 3 people south of Pryor in Mayes County. ^In 1993, an F4 tornado touched down in Catoosa. A second tornado, rated F3, touched down near a truck stop at I-44 and 161st East Avenue. Between the 2 tornadoes, 7 people were killed and 130 others were injured. Six of the fatalities occurred in cars near the truck stop.

In 1888, severe thunderstorms produced destructive wind and hail in Fort Smith. Several structures were damaged or destroyed, and small hail covered the ground to a depth of about 2 inches. ^In 1994, an F2 tornado hit Talihina, OK in LeFlore County and caused $2 million in damages. ^In 2011, the Baron Fork River at Eldon, OK and the Illinois River near Watts, OK reached record crests at 28.51 feet and 28.6 feet, respectively, after a significant rainfall event.

In 1984, a large tornado outbreak occurred from Oklahoma to the Great Lakes region. Terlton, OK was hit by an F4 tornado, which killed 3 people. An F3 tornado hit Morris, OK late that evening, killing 8 people and damaging about 70% of the structures in town. ^In 1991, an outbreak of 55 tornadoes tore through an area from Texas to Iowa. Several occurred in eastern Oklahoma, including a three violent F4 twisters. The towns of Westport, Skiatook and Oologah were hardest hit. One person was killed on U.S. Highway 412 near Westport, and another was killed in Copan. ^In 2016, a squall line moved across eastern Oklahoma and western Arkansas during the late evening into the early morning of the 27th. A total of 22 tornadoes (EF-0 and EF-1) were confirmed.

In 1942, a violent tornado moved through downtown Pryor, OK, killing 49 people and hospitalizing 181. Nearly a third of the town was destroyed. There were three other fatalities in rural locations southwest of Pryor. A second violent twister killed 4 in Rogers Co...one in a car thrown about 250 yards near Talala, OK, and 3 others in 3 different farm houses east of Talala. ^In 2011, a heavy rainfall event occurred, bringing up to 14 inches of rain in Adair County, OK and Benton and Washington counties in Arkansas. ^In 2014, an EF-2 tornado hit the town of Quapaw, OK, killing one person and injuring 12 others. The same tornado went on to cause significant damage in Baxter Springs, KS. This was the only strong (EF-2 or higher rating) tornado of the 16 confirmed in Oklahoma in 2014, which is the lowest number of tornadoes in the state since at least 1950.

In 1996, severe thunderstorms moved through northeast Oklahoma in the early morning. Winds were estimated at 100 to 115 mph, causing damage in the Cardin, Picher, and Quapaw areas in Ottawa County. U.S. Highway 69 was closed from Picher to the Kansas state line due to debris across the roadway. ^In 2017, a significant heavy rainfall event began, lasting into the 30th. Parts of east central OK and northwest AR received 5-12 inches of rain, resulting in flash flooding that claimed 6 lives. The Illinois River at Watts, OK eventually crested at a record 30.16 feet on the 30th.

In 1909, a tornado killed 1 person in Crawford County, AR. This was the beginning of a significant tornado outbreak in the Tennessee and Mississippi Valleys. ^In 1947, a violent tornado tore through Benton and Carroll Counties in northwest Arkansas. 9 people were killed and about 50 were injured. ^In 1984, the 3rd deadly tornado (F4) in less than a week hit Mannford, OK in Creek County. The tornado struck around 10 am on a Sunday morning. One person was killed and at least 20 were injured.

In 1947, a tornado killed 8 people in the farming communities of Bright Water and Garfield in Benton County, AR. The business section of Bright Water was almost destroyed. ^In 1949, several tornadoes hit central and eastern Oklahoma and northern Texas. 1 person was killed west of Spencerville, OK in Choctaw County, OK and 11 homes were destroyed. ^In 2019, severe thunderstorms developed over eastern OK early in the afternoon. Additional severe storms moved north out of TX into southeast OK later in the evening. 13 tornadoes were confirmed in eastern OK, including EF-2 tornadoes near Talala, OK and near Haileyville, OK. Heavy rain from the storms resulted in flash flooding, with one fatality reported in Tulsa, OK.

In 1948, 2 tornadoes hit the crowded Grand Lake area. The first tornado destroyed 14 farms in Craig County, OK before hitting Bernice, OK in Delaware County. The other tornado was about parallel to the first and damaged about a dozen cabins on Grand Lake. ^In 2009, Owasso, Claremore, and Pryor experienced flooding. 5 to 8 inches of rain fell in some areas. Pryor received about 5 inches of rain in one hour, with a storm total of over 7 inches. About 25 swift water rescues were performed near Pryor as a result of the ensuing flooding. ^In 2015, May would go down as the wettest month on record for the state of Oklahoma. Rainfall totals for the month along and south of I40 in eastern OK averaged from 20 to 25 inches, including a max of 27.70 inches 4 miles ESE of Hartshorne, OK (Pittsburg Co). These amounts were from 300-600% of normal for May, and would have less than a 0.1% annual chance (1,000-year event) of occurring in a given year!

In 1920, The deadliest tornado on record in the NWS Tulsa's forecast area struck Peggs, OK in Cherokee County, killing 71 people. This total represented about one-third of the town's population. The tornado was the third deadliest in Oklahoma history. Only 7 buildings in town remained standing.  4 others were killed and 8 injured near Chelsea, OK (Rogers Co) by another twister. ^In 1942, tornadoes struck northeast Oklahoma for the second time in a week, killing 26 people and injuring over 100 others. 10 people were killed at Childsville near Okemah, OK in Okfuskee County as the small community was nearly wiped off of the map.  Another tornado swept a 12-block area of a residential addition at the southeastern edge of Pawhuska, OK in Osage County, leaving 3 dead and 50 to 75 injured. A third deadly twister moved northwest of the Tulsa area, killing 3 north of Fisher, OK (near Sand Springs) and another 4 in Turley, OK (Tulsa Co). ^In 2013, a low pressure system with unseasonably cold air brought the latest snowfall on record to parts of northeast OK and northwest AR.  Heavier snow developed over far northeast Oklahoma, overnight into the morning of the 3rd in the higher elevations of southeast OK, and northwest AR, where snowfall totals of 1 to 2 inches were common.  The highest totals of 3 to 5 inches occurred in Adair County, OK and Benton County, AR.  This is the first time snow has fallen in the state of Arkansas during the month of May.

In 1999, one of the most devastating tornado outbreaks in state history occurred in central Oklahoma, including the devastating F5 tornado the struck the Oklahoma City metro area. Several tornadoes were reported across northeast Oklahoma and northwest Arkansas in the late evening hours of the 3rd, and again in the morning of the 4th. 2 storms moved northeast along the I-44 corridor, causing F3 damage in Stroud, OK and F1 damage in Sapulpa and parts of Tulsa. Another storm moved from southeast Oklahoma into northwest Arkansas, producing several damaging tornadoes. The last tornado hit Sequoyah County and tracked 39 miles to near Fayetteville, AR, producing F3 damage in Adair County.

In 1934, mid afternoon tornadoes hit northeast OK, killing 4 people and injuring over 30. A large tornado moved from Jenks, OK to south of Catoosa. Another twister hit south of South Coffeyville, OK in Nowata County, overturning a train. A third tornado hit east of Bartlesville, destroying a farm house. The debris whirled over the heads of a teacher and 25 students at a nearby school, who were caught inside. The teacher told the students to lay flat in the open when they were unable to reach shelter. ^In 2013, an unusual event occurred when snow fell over much of far northeast Oklahoma and northwest Arkansas on the 2nd through the 4th. Records were established for latest snowfall in Tulsa (May 2), and in the entire state of Arkansas (May 4). As much as 5 inches fell near Decatur, AR (Benton Co), with 3 inches at Westville, OK (Adair Co), Siloam Springs and Gentry, AR.

In 1960, a deadly outbreak of 18 tornadoes killed 32 people and injured at least 200 in eastern Oklahoma. 13 of those were killed in Wilburton, OK in Latimer County. The same twister killed 3 more in Keota in Haskell County. 5 people were killed in Creek County when an F5 tornado hit areas near Bristow and Sapulpa. Other deadly tornadoes struck McIntosh and Sequoyah counties. ^In 1961, one year to the date after a historic tornado outbreak in eastern Oklahoma, a violent tornado struck LeFlore Co, OK, moving from just south of Talihina to Howe, where 12 people were killed when a number of houses were leveled. 4 others were killed in Reichert. A total of 70 homes were destroyed and 58 people were injured.

In 1975, severe thunderstorms moved through the Fort Smith area, producing hail up to 2 inches in diameter. 2 mobile homes were destroyed by straight line winds and 3 were killed by flash floods. ^In 2000, heavy rains fell across eastern Oklahoma, with Kiefer in Creek County receiving up to 8 inches. The most flood damage occurred in Sapulpa where 150 homes and 12 businesses were damaged. Damage to roads and bridges in Creek County was estimated at $300,000. Tennis ball size hail also fell in Tulsa.

In 1926, a tornado killed 2 people and injured 23 near Okemah, OK in Okfuskee County. Over a dozen farms were destroyed and the funnel was reported to be up to a half-mile wide west of Okmulgee. Another strong tornado killed 4 people and injured 25 in LeFlore County. A third twister destroyed 10 homes in an oil lease community near Boynton, OK.

in 1882, a tornado in McAlester, which was then a small mining community killed 21 people and destroyed much of the town. ^In 1936, Tornadoes killed 3 and injured around 70 in eastern Oklahoma. A large twister struck the southeast edge of Gore, OK (Sequoyah Co), where at least 5 homes were swept away. 2 people died in one of them. The east side of Hanna, OK (McIntosh CO) was also hit with 1 death and 15 homes destroyed. The seriously injured were floated across flooded Mill Creek to get to a hospital.

In 1930, Tornadoes strike central and eastern Oklahoma, killing 7 and injuring 2 dozen. 2 deaths occurred northwest of Arpelar, OK (Pittsburg Co). 4 were killed and 15 injured south of Stigler, OK (Haskell Co) where 12 homes were destroyed. The last fatality occurred in the Hill 44 community near Bartlesville, OK (Washington, OK), where 3 homes and a gasoline plant were destroyed. ^In 1959, several tornadoes struck eastern Oklahoma. One twister near Strang in Mayes County destroyed some 40 farms, with 3 people injured. Another near Talala in Rogers County destroyed several farms, and hurled a school bus into a ditch as the passengers sought refuge in nearby culverts. ^In 2016, a strong, EF-3 tornado struck portions of western Choctaw Co near Boswell around 630 pm. The damage path was up to 1.8 miles  wide at one point. 2 people were injured. Another tornado from the same supercell storm caused EF-1 damage in Hugo.

In 1905, an F5 tornado went through Snyder, OK, killing at least 97 people. This was one of the deadliest tornadoes in OK history and ranks in the top 20 deadliest tornadoes in the U.S. ^In 2008, 14 tornadoes occurred across eastern Oklahoma and northwest Arkansas. Picher, OK was the hardest hit, experiencing an F4 twister that killed 6 people. ^In 2010, a supercell along I-40 produced several tornadoes and baseball sized hail across eastern Oklahoma and northwest Arkansas. The storm produced numerous F1 tornadoes and an F2.

In 1992, a significant tornado outbreak occurred in central and eastern Oklahoma. 22 tornadoes occurred that day, including an F4 near Kiowa, OK that injured 3 people and damaged or destroyed several homes. ^In 2015, the first wave of heavy rainfall during the month inundated much of eastern OK and western AR from May 6-11. Locations south of Highway 412 received over 4 inches of rain, with widespread 7 to 10 inch totals near and south of I-40.  For reference, this is approximately twice the normal rainfall for this area for the entire month of May. This rainfall led to 1 Major and 6 Moderate floods on area rivers, including a crest of 43.54 feet on the Poteau River at Panama, OK on the 12th, the 6th highest on record for this location. One flood related fatality occurred near Spiro, OK (LeFlore Co) on the 11th, and another occurred on the 12th near Rudy, AR (Crawford Co).

In 1933, a strong tornado hit Skiatook, OK in Osage County, killing 5 people and injuring 11 others. 20 homes were also damaged. ^In 1950, record flooding occurred on the Illinois River near Tahlequah on the 11th and 12th. The newly constructed Fort Gibson reservoir filled one year ahead of predictions.

In 2004, severe thunderstorms produced damaging winds in northeast Oklahoma. Glenpool and Mounds reported 80 mph winds and an F1 tornado developed in Coweta. ^In 2010, a large complex of thunderstorms spawned several tornadoes across northeast Oklahoma in the early morning hours. An EF1 tornado developed in Sapulpa, causing $25 million in damages, before moving into Tulsa County and producing EF2 damage. Several other tornadoes developed from the line of storms and caused significant damage in Tulsa, Rogers and Wagoner counties.

In 1967, a line of severe thunderstorms moved through the Tulsa area. The path was from south Sapulpa to Tulsa and Inola. The storm produced 2 inch hail and 70 mph wind gusts, with storm damage estimated to be $5 million. ^In 1996, severe thunderstorms moved across northeast Oklahoma, producing large hail throughout the Tulsa area. Reports included: baseball size in Broken Arrow and Oneta, tennis ball size in Jenks, and hen egg size in Glenpool.

In 1943, a tornado outbreak from Oklahoma to Illinois occurred. At least 5 strong tornadoes hit northeast Oklahoma. 1 person was killed and 8 others injured, all in the same home, north of Choteau, OK (Mayes Co). Other damage was reported in Creek Co, at Coweta (Wagoner Co), near Haskell (Muskogee Co) and near Welty (Okfuskee Co). ^In 1990, a few tornadoes hit northeast Oklahoma. An F2 touched down in Adair in Mayes County, causing $250,000 in damage.

In 1928, a tornado struck the community of Silver City, OK in Creek County, killing one person, and destroying 5 homes and a dance hall. About 60 people had just left the dance hall when the tornado hit around 11 pm. The man killed was hit by flying timber as he was getting in his car. About 10 people were injured near the dance hall and 5 others were hurt on nearby farms. ^In 1999, A cluster of thunderstorms formed over western Oklahoma and quickly moved east across eastern Oklahoma late in the evening. Damaging winds swept across nearly all of eastern Oklahoma into the very early morning of May 17. The strongest winds occurred from near Okemah through Muskogee County and on to Westville. While there were numerous reports of wind damage, Muskogee County saw the most serious damage, including several injuries when winds toppled mobile homes. ^In 2009, between April 25th and May 16th, at least a trace of rain fell in Tulsa every day. These 22 days of consecutive rain set an all-time record. ^In 2015, a line of severe storms, along with a few discrete supercells ahead of the QLCS, produced 9 tornadoes in northeast OK late in the evening into the early morning of the 17th, including EF2 twisters in Broken Arrow, OK and near Inola, OK. Heavy rain on top of already saturated soils led to flash flooding from Pittsburg County, OK to southern Washington County, AR.  Several state and US highways were closed due to high water.

In 1981, several tornadoes struck central and eastern Oklahoma. A large tornado tracked from north of Okemah to the Okmulgee Lake area, damaging or destroying several homes, outbuildings and a church. 2 people were injured. Softball size hail was associated with the storm. Another large tornado (up to a mile wide) was observed in rural Osage County, but, luckily, no damage was reported. Other tornadoes were also reported in Greenleaf State Park and near Shidler, OK in Osage County. ^In 1993, severe thunderstorms developed along a cold front and moved into northeast Oklahoma during the early evening. The storms then moved southeast across most of eastern Oklahoma during the evening, producing widespread wind damage and one small tornado.

In 1989, several tornadoes occurred in northeast Oklahoma and northwest Arkansas. An F2 touched down just north of Van Buren, AR, where 10 houses were damaged and 2 church buses were overturned. F1 tornadoes hit Claremore and Broken Arrow, OK. The twister in Claremore hit an exotic animal farm, killing an emu. Between the two tornadoes there was $175,000 in damages. A pair of F0 tornado also occurred near Pryor. ^In 2017, a line of severe thunderstorms spawned at least 16 tornadoes in east central OK and northwest AR during the late evening into very early the next morning. Most were rated EF-0 or EF-1, however EF-2 damage occurred near Hanna, OK (McIntosh Co) and on the north side of Muskogee, OK. ^In 2019, a persistent pattern of wet and stormy weather began across eastern OK and western AR that would continue through the end of May. Anywhere from 6 to 16 inches of rain fell generally NW of a line from Okmulgee, OK to Bentonville, AR on already saturated ground from earlier rains. This along with heavy rain across southern KS led to a historic river flooding event, with a total of 34 river flood events affecting 25 forecast points. Record floods were ultimately observed on the Arkansas River at Ponca City, OK and Van Buren, AR, and on Bird Creek at Avant, OK, with major flooding also observed on the Neosho, Spring, Caney and Verdigris Rivers. 6 reservoirs would eventually set new pools of record in the NWS Tulsa HSA: Kaw, Keystone, Skiatook, Birch, Oologah, and Hudson.

In 1990, severe thunderstorms with powerful wind and heavy rainfall caused wind damage in Vian, OK in Sequoyah County and flash flooding in Osage County. ^In 2010, four weak (F0/F1) tornadoes moved through Okfuskee and Creek counties in eastern Oklahoma, damaging a few homes and uprooting trees. ^In 2015, another round of heavy rainfall along and south of I-40 occurred, with widespread 1.5 to 4 inch amounts of rain. Portions of Haskell, Le Flore, Latimer, Pushmataha, and Pittsburg Counties saw 4 to 7 inches of rain on top of saturated soils, leading to widespread, extensive flash flooding. Flood waters inundated numerous buildings in Talihina, OK (Le Flore Co.), including the housing authority, the Choctaw Nation Hospital, the high school, and a nursing home. Numerous roads were under water across the area as well.

In 1898, a strong tornado touched down in Benton County, Arkansas, moving from near Tontitown to southeast of Rogers. The twister killed 5 people: 3 in one home near Springdale and 2 others near Elm Springs. A number of homes were destroyed along the twister's path, and 11 people were injured. ^In 2001, severe thunderstorms occurred in eastern Oklahoma and northwest Arkansas, producing large hail and several tornadoes. An F1 tornado developed in Hughes County and entered McIntosh County 7 miles northwest of Hanna, OK. The tornado lifted 5 miles north of Hanna, and damaged a McDonald's restaurant on the Indian Nation Turnpike and overturned a large truck. Softball size hail also fell in Fort Smith. Considerable Straight line wind damage occurred in Porum, OK and Stigler, OK. The storms throughout the day produced 8 tornadoes in Oklahoma and 3 in Arkansas, most rated F0. ^In 2013, on the same day that an EF-5 tornado struck Moore, OK,  12 tornadoes struck eastern Oklahoma, including a strong EF-2 twister north of Wyandotte, OK in Ottawa County.

In 1957, the Arkansas River in Tulsa rose to 21.53 feet. 22 feet is considered major flood stage, so this was a significant flooding, and marked the 5th highest crest on record for the Arkansas River at Tulsa. ^In 2019, a total of 28 tornadoes were confirmed within the NWS Tulsa CWA in the 48 hour period from the evening of May 20 through the evening of May 22, a  record for number of tornadoes in a 48 hour period in this area. A new record was also established for a 7 day period, with 41 tornadoes confirmed between May 18 and May 22. The most significant tornadoes were an EF-2 tornado that injured one person near Peggs, OK late in the evening of the 20th, and an EF-2 near Jay, OK in the evening of the 22nd.

In 1971, severe thunderstorms produced powerful winds and a tornado. Wind damage was reported in Pryor, OK where 3 people were injured when a mobile home was overturned. The tornado hit Grove, damaging several homes, buses, and 5 planes at the airport. ^In 2011, one of the deadliest single tornadoes in modern history occurred, when an F5 tornado devastated Joplin, MO, causing 158 fatalities and over 1000 injuries. The same evening, 12 tornadoes touched down in northeast Oklahoma and in Benton County, AR. An F3 tornado struck Delaware County, OK, causing $1 million in damages and injuring two people. Several homes were damaged or destroyed near Zena from the 140 mph winds. 12 people were injured by an F2 twister near West Siloam Springs, OK, where 6 mobile homes were destroyed.

In 1981, several tornadoes touched down in eastern Oklahoma. 2 tornadoes about a mile apart also hit Copan and South Coffeyville, injuring 6 people and causing $300,000 in damages. Tornadoes also caused damage near Hominy in Osage County and Colcord in Delaware County.
