Other tornadoes touched down near Bristow and Lenapah. ^In 2011, a hailstone measuring 6 inches in diameter was found 2 miles north of Gotebo, Oklahoma, establishing a new Oklahoma state record for largest diameter of hail. Also this day, up to 10 inches of rain fell across Nowata, Craig, and Ottawa Counties, leading to extensive flash flooding. 4 to 6 inches of rainfall across northwest Arkansas also resulted in flash flooding. Four people were killed when their car was swept away near Gallatin, AR. The heavy rain caused the Illinois River near Watts, OK to reach major flood stage for the second time in a month. ^In 2015, more heavy rainfall led to another round of deadly flooding. In just a 2-day period from the 23rd to the 24th, all of eastern OK and western AR received from 2 to nearly 8 inches of rain on top of already saturated soil. A Flash Flood Emergency was issued for the Tulsa metro area, where 55 water-related emergency responses were made between 9 and 11pm. Many roads in the Tulsa metro area were flooded, some to several feet. Four fatalities occurred from the heavy rain, including a Claremore, OK (Rogers Co) firefighter. Other fatalities occurred in Sapulpa, OK (Creek Co), and at Lake Eufaula (McIntosh Co). 19 of 33 river forecast points in the area rose above flood stage, many reaching moderate and major flood stage, and several remained above flood stage for a week or more.

In 2011, a significant tornado outbreak struck central and eastern Oklahoma in the evening, and continued into west central Arkansas after midnight. A total of 11 tornadoes were confirmed in the Tulsa forecast areas A violent F4 tornado moved through Franklin County, AR around midnight, killing two people in Denning and one other in Etna. At least $3 million in damages were associated with this twister, along with 16 injuries. The same system was responsible for 3 violent tornadoes in the Oklahoma City area, which killed 11 people, including 9 fatalities from an F5 tornado near Piedmont, OK.

In 1994, severe thunderstorms developed in northeast Oklahoma, producing strong winds and hail. Thunderstorm winds caused extensive damage in Tulsa and Broken Arrow. Winds downed signs and overturned a U-Haul trailer near 51st St and Highway 169. Several power lines/poles and trees were also downed, and dime to nickel size hail fell in several areas. Heavy rains from the storms caused flash flooding in Rogers, Delaware, and Tulsa Counties, closing several streets. ^In 2015, a complex of severe storms moved across southeast OK and west central AR. Four tornadoes struck southeast OK, including strong (EF-2) tornadoes in Latimer County and near Poteau (LeFlore Co). The additional rainfall resulted in more rapid-onset flash flooding and mainstem river flooding, which included the 4th and highest crest of the long duration moderate flood along the Kiamichi River near Antlers, OK. Both Wister and Hugo Lakes set new pool of record by the end of the day.

In 1915, a tornado touched down in Talihina, OK in LeFlore County, OK. The twister caused 2 fatalities, 4 injuries, and damaged at least 12 homes and 8 businesses. ^In 1971, severe thunderstorms moved through northeast Oklahoma in the late afternoon and evening. Wind gusts to 91 mph were measured at Riverside airport in Jenks, OK. Significant wind damage occurred in the Tulsa area, with one fatality and 75 injuries. Other areas affected by wind damage were Fairfax, Sapulpa, Pawnee, and Wagoner. The storms also produced golf ball sized hail that accumulated up to 8 inches deep in Pawnee County. ^In 1973, an outbreak of tornadoes struck eastern Oklahoma and northwest Arkansas. An F4 tornado hit the town of Keefeton, OK in Muskogee County, killing 5 and injuring at least 2 dozen others. Approximately 3/4 of Keefeton suffered some degree of damage. Four of the fatalities occurred when a pickup truck was rolled and carried for about 1/2 mile, while the other occurred in one of the destroyed homes. Other significant damage occurred in Sequoyah Co, OK, where 9 homes were destroyed and 47 others damaged, in Wister, OK (LeFlore Co), and near Berryville, AR (Carroll Co).

In 1912, a violent tornado struck Skiatook, OK (Osage County), killing 7 people and injuring 30. 20 homes were swept away on the southwest side of town, with five fatalities occurring in one of them. ^In 1984, a catastrophic Memorial Day weekend flood occurred in Tulsa as a result of 12 to 15 inches of rainfall in the Mingo Creek basin. The floods killed 14 people and injured 288, and caused $180 million in damages (1984 dollars). In the aftermath of the flood, the City of Tulsa began an aggressive floodplain maintenance and storm water management program and started a public awareness program that has been the model for other cities across the nation.

In 1924, several tornadoes struck eastern Oklahoma and northwest Arkansas. One tornado struck  Warner, OK (Muskogee Co) causing heavy damage downtown. Two people were killed and 15 injured in a downtown hotel. A hat with a price tag from a Warner store was eventually found 40 miles away in Muldrow, OK (Sequoyah Co.). The same twister killed 3 others south of Muldrow. Another tornado killed one and injured 10 in Summers, AR (Washington Co), while another killed one, injured eight and caused expensive property damage in Farmington, AR (Washington Co). Three other people were killed and 50 injured by a strong tornado in Haskell and LeFlore counties; one fatality was reported near Stigler, one in Keota,  and one more near Cowlington. About 100 others were left homeless by this twister. ^In 1982, three F2 tornadoes occurred in eastern Oklahoma between 1AM and 3AM. These occurred in Sallisaw, Antlers, and Octavia. Several structures were damaged or destroyed, and power was not restored in Antlers until early the next evening.

In 1909, a tornado touched down northwest of Micawber, OK in Creek County, killing 4 people. Another person was killed by a tornado that hit Depew, OK in Creek County, where half of the town was damaged or destroyed. Ten other deaths were attributed to flash flooding. ^In 2004, an upper level low pressure system moved into the Great Plains during the Memorial Day Weekend, producing 93 reported tornadoes. One individual supercell traveled 300 miles across Oklahoma in almost 12 hours. At least a dozen tornadoes were produced by this one cell, including an F3 that struck near Depew in Creek Co. late that evening.

In 1976, severe weather and flooding struck northeast Oklahoma on Memorial Day. A destructive flood in Tulsa was caused by a 7 to 10 inch deluge of rainfall in about 3 hours on the south side of the city. Flash floods along Haikey Creek and Mingo Creek caused 3 fatalities and $40 million in damages (1976 dollars). Two tornadoes were also reported. One touched down on the Turner Turnpike in Creek County, picking up a motor home and carrying it into the oncoming lane, killing one passenger and injuring two others. The other twister caused damage to a trailer park near the Muskogee Turnpike in Wagoner County, and injured four people. ^In 2013, The second outbreak of tornadoes in 10 days produced 4 tornadoes in eastern Oklahoma, including an EF-2 that struck parts of Broken Arrow.

In 2005, May was a very quiet severe weather month compared to the normal. In fact, there were no tornadoes in Oklahoma in the entire month of May. This is the only time since records began in 1950 that this has occurred! ^In 2006, Oklahoma and Arkansas concluded the warmest meteorological spring (March 1 - May 31) on record. It was also the warmest spring on record in Fort Smith. ^In 2013, the same supercell storm that produced a deadly tornado and flash flooding in the OKC area tracked along I-40 into eastern Oklahoma and remained a prolific rain producer, bringing widespread 3-8 of much of east central Oklahoma. This heavy rain resulted in widespread flash flooding, and unfortunately, one fatality. A number of evacuations and water rescues became necessary in the towns of Weleetka (Okfuskee Co), Henryetta and Dewar (Okmulgee Co). ^In 2015, heavy rains in May helped make the spring (March-May) the wettest on record for southeast OK and at Fort Smith, AR. It was also the 3rd wettest spring at Tulsa, OK.

In 1917, several tornadoes struck Oklahoma, including three reported in the eastern part of the state. An F4 tornado killed 14 people and injured at least 100 others in Coalgate, OK (WFO Norman area). A book from Coalgate was found within the walls of the State Prison in McAlester, 40 miles away! ^In 1999, a tornado outbreak hit eastern Oklahoma, with 9 total tornadoes, including two F3 and one F2. Two people were killed in Hulbert, OK in Cherokee County by the F3 twister, which damaged or destroyed at least 68 homes.

In 1897, a tornado struck the 'David' community near Chelsea, OK (Rogers County), killing 2 people and injuring 8. At least 13 homes were destroyed and according to one report, the tornado tracked about 30 miles. ^In 1990, an F1 tornado hit 4 miles south of Greenwood, AR, damaging several homes. ^In 2004, thunderstorm winds estimated near 80 miles an hour struck downtown Tulsa during the early afternoon and blew glass windows out of the Adams Mark Hotel downtown. Not far away, the Wiltel building received structural damage to its northeast facade including several broken glass windows. One person was injured by the breaking glass. Areas just to the south and southeast side of downtown suffered major power outages which took days to completely fix. As many as 70,000 Tulsa area customers were without power at the peek of the outage. The same thunderstorm complex went on to produce wind damage throughout eastern Oklahoma and northwest Arkansas, including the city of Fort Smith.

In 1993, severe thunderstorms developed in northeast Oklahoma during the early morning and produced very large hail. One particularly severe storm moved across Creek and Okmulgee Counties before dissipating in Muskogee County. Softball size hail fell at Beggs, and baseball to softball size hail fell at Bristow and 5 miles south of Bristow. Numerous windshields were broken by the hail in Bristow. Baseball size hail fell at Slick, where hail broke through the roof of one mobile home and through the siding of another home.

In 1973, severe thunderstorms struck eastern Oklahoma during the early evening. A tornado touched down near Oilton, OK (Creek Co.), badly damaging one rural home and damaging a pump house nearby. Another twister caused minor damage in Barnsdall, OK (Osage Co), while straight line wind damage was reported near Wynona (Osage Co.) and near Okemah (Okfuskee Co.). ^In 2005, severe storms caused widespread wind damage across eastern Oklahoma and northwest Arkansas in the late evening of the 4th into the early morning of the 5th. A heat burst produced wind gusts up to 70 mph in and around the Tulsa metro area, which resulted in downed trees, large tree limbs, and power lines. Strong thunderstorm winds destroyed a mobile home southwest of Burbank, OK (Osage Co). Five people were injured inside the mobile home when the storm hit, with three seriously injured and hospitalized. A weak tornado also touched down in Osage County, rolling a modular home off its foundation east of McCord, OK.

In 1908, severe flooding occurred in Pawnee, OK, destroying a number of bridges in Pawnee County and taking several lives. ^In 1916, a significant late-season tornado outbreak began in western Arkansas. There was 1 death and 5 injuries near Ozark, AR in Franklin County. Near Greenland, AR in Washington County there was 1 death, 12 injuries, and 16 damaged homes. The outbreak was responsible for 110 other deaths in Arkansas, Missouri, Illinois and Mississippi.

In 2006, a damaging microburst struck parts of Tulsa at around 6 am. There was extensive damage north to south from 11th Street to 21st Street and from east to west from Yale to the Broken Arrow Expressway. Wind speeds were estimated at 85 miles an hour based on the damage. 1420 homes were damaged, two of which received major damage as large trees were blown down onto them. At one time, 13,000 residents near the damaged area were without power. There was extensive damage at the fairgrounds and nearby Bell's Amusement Park; most notably roof damage at the trade center and exchange center, and the 80 year old Ferris wheel at Bell's being destroyed. There were four minor injuries. ^In 2019, The Neosho River at Commerce, OK dropped below flood stage for the first time in 28 days. At the same time, however, thunderstorms with very heavy rainfall rates developed over northeast OK and western AR late in the day. The Tulsa, OK Mesonet site recorded just over 3 inches of rain in an hour, and these rainfall rates resulted in considerable flash flooding in the city of Tulsa. Flash flooding also occurred in and around Fayetteville, AR, where as much as 7 inches of rain fell.

In 1966, severe thunderstorms struck Muskogee County in eastern Oklahoma shortly after noon. An estimated wind gust of 105 mph was recorded at Davis Field in Muskogee. The official wind gauge recorded gusts to 90 mph when it broke...the maximum speed was estimated after that. A mobile home attached to a foundation was blown over in Muskogee, and two farm houses were damaged in Summit.

In 1974, one of the more significant severe weather and flooding events to strike eastern Oklahoma came in two waves. The day began with torrential downpours of rain over eastern Oklahoma and northwest Arkansas, causing significant flooding. One person died near Chewey, OK (Adair Co.) and another in Tahlequah, OK (Cherokee Co). As much as 11 inches of rain fell in Siloam Springs, AR (Benton CO). Late that afternoon, a tornado outbreak began over central Oklahoma and continued through the eastern part of the state, producing 22 tornadoes in all. Eight of them were F3 and one was rated an F4. The first tornado of the afternoon struck the National Weather Service office in Oklahoma City and caused minor damage. An F4 tornado touched down near Drumright, OK (Creek Co.) and tore through the town, leaving 12 dead and scores injured. Six of the fatalities were in a nursing home on the northwest side of town. Two others were killed in Creek County. Two strong tornadoes tore through Tulsa shortly after that, with torrential rains also leading to flash flooding. One person was killed by one of the twisters, while two others died in the flooding. At the time, this was considered the costliest natural disaster to ever strike Tulsa.

In 1937, several tornadoes struck central and eastern Oklahoma and northwest Arkansas. One tornado moved from the west edge of Green Forest, AR in Carroll County, east into Boone County. 1 person was killed, 50 were injured, and a dozen homes were damaged or destroyed in Green Forest. A canning factory was also hit in Green Forest. ^In 1993, 11 counties in northeast and east central Oklahoma, from the Tulsa area east to Adair County, received damaging winds from a line of severe thunderstorms. 4 weak tornadoes occurred within a few miles of Tulsa.

In 1911, an early June heat wave saw record were established in Tulsa each day from the 2nd through the 10th, when the temperature hit a monthly record of 108 degrees. These records are still in tact over 100 years later, including the all-time high for the month. 1911 remains Tulsa's hottest June on record by over a degree. ^In 1995, The first ten days of June were marked by repeated rounds of severe thunderstorms and several rounds of heavy rainfall. Bartlesville, OK recorded a little over 10 inches of rainfall in that period, on their way to over 15 inches for the month. ^In 2009, severe storms moved across southeast Oklahoma and west central Arkansas, with wind gusts up to 100 mph reported in Pittsburg and Sequoyah Counties. 2 brief tornadoes were reported in Haskell County.

In 1970, a tornado outbreak struck central and eastern Oklahoma into northwest Arkansas. Three deaths were reported from three separate tornadoes. One fatality occurred in Vinita, OK and another in one of three  trailer communities struck near Lake Eufaula in Pittsburg County, OK. 21 trailers and a gas station were destroyed. A likely family of tornadoes caused significant damage along a 55 mile path from near Bunch, OK in Adair County to near Springdale, AR in Washington County. Springdale was the hardest hit, with damage to 138 buildings. 1 person was killed and 44 were injured.

In 2007, Washington and Nowata Counties experienced flash flooding. Wann, OK in Nowata County received 8.93 inches of rain in 24 hours. In Washington County, damaging floods occurred in Dewey as Coon Creek overflowed into the Meadowcreek subdivision and into a mobile home park.  Portions of Highway 75 and Highway 123 were closed because of high water. The flooding of Coon Creek was further aggravated as it could not empty into the Caney River, which was undergoing moderate flooding at Bartlesville. ^In 2009, the second complex of severe storms in a 3 day period brought more widespread wind damage during the morning and early afternoon, especially in the Fort Smith area and near Ozark, AR.

In 1923, significant flooding along the Arkansas River from the 11th through the 13th impacted Tulsa's waterworks, displacing 4,000 people and causing $500,000 ($11.94 million in 1994 dollars) in damages. ^In 1960, severe storms struck east central Oklahoma. 80 mph winds occurred in Okmulgee, damaging 2 homes. Wind damage was also reported in Eufaula (McIntosh Co). Baseball size hail hit Quinton, OK (Pittsburg Co.) and 2.5 inch hail fell in Big Cedar, OK (LeFlore Co). ^In 2019, the Arkansas River at Ozark Lock and Dam Tailwater fell below flood stage. This marked the first time since May 20 (just under 24 days), that at no rivers in the NWS Tulsa HSA were above flood stage.

In 1985, severe thunderstorms hit eastern Oklahoma. An F1 tornado was reported near Owasso, OK, causing a barn and house to be unroofed and 10 houses to be damaged. There was also $250,000 in damages in Owasso from 3 inch hail and 80 mph winds. Significant wind damage also occurred in Tulsa and Mannford. Hail damage of around 1 million dollars occurred near Cleveland, OK (Pawnee Co). ^In 2001, thunderstorm winds estimated at 70 miles an hour damaged the roofs of two houses and a barn near Alderson, OK (Pittsburg Co.), and winds estimated at 70 miles an hour uprooted a large tree and destroyed an outbuilding in Higgins, OK (Latimer Co).

In 1912, a tornado passed through Nelogany, OK in Osage County, killing 1 person where large farm house was leveled before the eyes of awe-struck spectators. A second twister destroyed 7 homes and heavily damaged 27 others in Collinsville, OK (Tulsa Co). ^In 1982, a flash flood occurred in Fayetteville, AR after the area received 7.8 inches of rain. There was widespread flooding in Washington, Madison, Benton, and Adair Counties and 1 person was injured in Gentry.

In 1973, a tornado with a 30 mile path occurred 6 miles north of McAlester, OK, damaging 2 mobile homes and injuring 2 people. The twister moved across Lake Eufaula near Arrowhead Lodge, damaging several boat docks there. ^In 1997, severe thunderstorms moved across east central Oklahoma during the late afternoon. Hail as large as 5.5 inches in diameter hail fell 3 miles north of  Eufaula (McIntosh Co.), and softball size hail damaged a house and  broke car windshields 5 miles north of Eufaula.  Wind gusts up to 100 miles an hour were reported in Henryetta, while winds estimated at 80 miles an hour caused considerable damage near Mason (Okfuskee Co). The storms also spawned 4 brief tornadoes.

In 1975, severe thunderstorms caused extensive wind damage in northwest Arkansas just after midnight. Allen Canning Company in Siloam Springs suffered major damage, and 10 minor injuries were reported. In Mayes and Wagoner counties in Oklahoma, winds gusted as high as 100 mph, with 18 injuries reported. ^In 1980, Severe storms with heavy rain struck northeast Oklahoma late in the evening of the 16th and very early in the morning of the 17th. Tulsa received 6-10 inches of rain within 2 days, with a number of homes suffering minor flood damage. Several homes and businesses were also damaged by flooding in Pawnee County. Severe storms shortly after midnight damaged a cabin and 3 mobile homes near Okemah Lake.

In 1998, an approaching cold front and a vigorous upper level low moving into the southern plains helped ignite an outbreak of severe thunderstorms in the late afternoon into early the next morning. The severe weather outbreak included baseball size hail, damaging thunderstorm winds, and a brief tornado touchdown 5 miles west of Porter, OK. ^In 2015, the remnants of Tropical Storm 'Bill' brought heavy rainfall of 2 to 5 inches to much of eastern OK and northwest AR on the 17th and 18th, with up to 12 inches in parts of south central OK. With soils nearly saturated from excessive spring rainfall, the rain resulted in both flash flooding and river flooding. The Red River at Arthur City, TX and the Deep Fork River at Beggs, OK both reached major flood stage

In 1992, severe thunderstorms with winds up to 100 mph left a swath of damage across Osage and Tulsa Counties, with estimates of $2-3 million in damages. Some of the most significant damage occurred in the towns of Prue, Hominy and Glenpool. Wind damage also occurred farther south in Haskell and Pittsburg counties. ^In 1996, severe thunderstorms moved across eastern Oklahoma and west central Arkansas during the evening into the early morning of the 19th. The storms produced damaging winds up to 90 mph and large hail in an area from the south side of the Tulsa metro area, eastward into Franklin County, AR. ^In 2004, flash flooding occurred in Sebastian County, AR as thunderstorms produced in excess of 2 inches of rain in a short period of time during the late afternoon. Both Fort Smith and Greenwood saw significant flooding to homes and businesses.

In 1928, a series of tornadoes swept across northeast Oklahoma. One person was killed in South Coffeyville, OK (Nowata Co)...16 other persons who had fled the storm after a fishing trip and sought shelter at the homes of the victim and her neighbor were injured when two homes were struck by the storm. One other fatality occurred near Webb City in Osage County. ^In 1999, a flash flood occurred when a cluster of slow-moving thunderstorms developed early in the morning and produced torrential rainfall over parts of northeast Oklahoma. Mayes County, OK was the hardest hit, with radar estimating four to seven inches of rain over a large part of the county. One man died when his car was swept off of Highway 28 near Adair. Significant flooding also occurred in the downtown section of Chelsea (Rogers Co).

In 1998, a nearly stationary broken line of thunderstorms developed from western Osage County southeast into the city of Tulsa just after midnight.
