Over 50 mph winds occurred in Rogers, Muskogee, & Mayes Counties. ^In 2015, following the record spring and early summer rainfall, a stretch of well below normal rainfall and hot weather across parts of southeast OK in July and August resulted in a 'flash' drought. By the end of August, severe drought conditions returned to Choctaw and southern Pushmataha counties, and would persist into the early part of November. ^In 2019, Fort Smith, AR totaled 11.70 inches of rain, the wettest August on record. It was also the wettest August on record for the northeast OK climate division with some locations seeing nearly 500% of normal August rainfall.

In 2000, a severe thunderstorm moved though northwest Arkansas. A billboard was blown down in Crawford County, some poultry houses and a few building were damaged in Franklin County, large tree limbs were blown down in Madison County. Fort Smith in Sebastian County received $100,000 in damages. Damage included signs, roofs, windows, power lines, and trees. ^In 2016, Fayetteville would experience its warmest autumn (Sep-Nov) on record, while Tulsa and both Fort Smith saw their 2nd warmest autumn. ^In 2019, much above normal temperatures persisted throughout September, making it the warmest September on record at Fayetteville, AR, and the 2nd warmest to both Tulsa and Fort Smith. While no daily record highs were broken at any locations, several record high daily minimums were established at Tulsa and Fayetteville.

In 1966, severe thunderstorms in northeast Oklahoma brought heavy rainfall to Washington, Osage, and Tulsa Counties. As much as 5. 5 inches of rain fell in Broken Arrow, causing extensive street flooding. Straight line winds in Collinsville severely damaged 1 home, and 1 person received minor injuries.

In 1970, severe thunderstorms produced a tornado 3 miles north of Welch, OK, damaging several barns and one home. There was also a brief tornado in Rogers County. In Crawford County, AR, 3 mobile homes were severely damaged and multiple homes received roof damage from straight-line winds.

In 1998,  the high temperature of 109 degrees was the hottest temperature ever recorded in the month of September in Fort Smith. The high temperature in McAlester reached 110 degrees, not only breaking the daily temperature record but also making this the hottest September day on record. The high temperature at the Tulsa International Airport was 107 degrees, tying the previous record high temperature for the date.  In addition, the low temperature for the day at Tulsa was 80 degrees, making this the warmest low temperature on record for the date.

In 1992, severe thunderstorms moved through northeast Oklahoma from the late evening into the morning of the 6th. Vinita received wind damage to several roofs and a storage building was destroyed. Strong winds in Tulsa blew over a tent at a festival, injuring one person. In 1998, Fort Smith set a record high temperature at 109 degrees for the second consecutive day, tying the all-time monthly record.

In 1971, flash flooding occurred in northeastern Oklahoma. Tulsa received 7.63 inches of rain in 3 days, resulting in extensive flood damage, including  $1 million in damages to a storage building's  roof when it collapsed. Many homes flooded and there were 2 fatalities. Okmulgee received 8.5 inches of rain, flooding several streets.

In 2001, severe thunderstorms developed in eastern Oklahoma. 60-70 mph winds were widespread throughout the area, and almost all of our forecast area of eastern Oklahoma reported severe weather. Okemah, Stilwell, Finley, and Kiowa received 70 mph winds. Damage included barns, trees, power poles, garages, a trailer, and the roof to the Stilwell football stadium's press box. ^In 2012, Severe thunderstorms developed ahead of and along a strong cold front that moved into the region after a week of record-breaking heat. A large supercell storm developed over Washington County, OK and moved eastward across Nowata County. This storm produced significant damage across central Nowata County as a result of hail up to baseball size and wind gusts of 80 to 100 mph. The winds destroyed a double wide mobile home, killing three occupants. At least two other nearby mobile homes were destroyed, while a number of permanent homes suffered roof and siding damage. A number of steel-framed or wood-framed outbuildings were also heavily damaged.  The line of storms subsequently produced numerous reports of damaging wind across northeast and east-central OK and much of northwest AR during the evening.

In 1992, 6 F0 tornadoes were spawned by isolated supercells in Rogers and Mayes Counties. Each county received 3 tornadoes, with only minor damage reported. 100 mph straight-line wind gusts were reported 6 miles ESE of Claremore, causing a roof of a church to be blown off. Baseball size hail was reported 5 miles west of Foyil, and 1-1.5 inch hail fell for 31 minutes in Pryor.

In 1900, the remnants of the Galveston Hurricane caused flooding in eastern Oklahoma, then Indian Territory. This hurricane remains the deadliest natural disaster in U.S. history, with an estimated 8000 people killed. Tropical storm force winds were noted as far north as the upper Midwest...in all likelihood at least tropical storm winds were observed in Oklahoma and Arkansas as well. ^In 2010, the remnants of Tropical Storm Hermine brought very heavy rain and widespread flash floods to parts of the area September 7-9. Rainfall rates of over 2 inches per hour and rainfall totals of 8 to 14 inches, mainly north of a McAlester to Fort Smith line, and south of a Tulsa to Fayetteville line, led to widespread flash flooding.

In 1999, severe thunderstorms developed in eastern Oklahoma. The storms moved SE from Tulsa, and an outflow boundary over north-central Oklahoma allowed more storms to be initiated from an upper level disturbance in the evening. The storms that evening moved SE along the outflow boundary from Pawnee County to Okfuskee County. A damaging tornado with 80 mph winds and baseball size hail occurred in Okfuskee County. Another tornado (F1) developed 3 miles north of Castle, and moved 3.5 miles to the SE. The tornado ripped off a roof of a home, and damaged a trailer roof.

In 1986, a severe thunderstorm caused wind damage in Morrow and Canehill in Washington County, AR. ^In 1995, isolated severe thunderstorms moved across northeast Oklahoma during the evening. Strong winds tore down large tree limbs near Burbank, OK (Osage County) and 4-inch-diameter tree limbs were torn down in Ralston (Pawnee County).

In 1989, severe thunderstorms developed in the late evening, causing wind damage near Okemah and Henryetta. Henryetta received 98 mph winds, damaging 20 houses and 5 mobile homes. There were $250,000 in damages and 4 people were injured. An F1 tornado also touched down near Henryetta, OK.

In 1998, Tropical Storm Frances moved onshore the Texas coast on September 11, bringing rainfall to eastern Oklahoma on September 12th as the system moved north. Very heavy rainfall continued with this system through the 14th, with two-day totals of 6 to 8 inches common across far eastern OK.

In 1915, 9.55 inches of rain fell in Osage County, OK causing significant flooding in Pawhuska. ^In 2008, Hurricane Ike made landfall near Galveston, Texas on the 13th and moved northward then northeastward into Arkansas by the early morning of the 14th. The combination of a cold front passing into the region and the proximity of the tropical storm to the area resulted in high winds across portions of far eastern OK and western AR. Trees, large tree limbs, and power lines were blown down, and some trees fell onto and blocked roads while some others fell on homes and businesses in northwest AR. Many areas in northwest AR were without power during the passage of the storm. Localized flash flooding occurred and eventually some river flooding resulted from Ike's rainfall.

In 1987, severe thunderstorms moved through northeast OK, bringing wind damage to Creek, Tulsa, Craig, and Rogers Counties. 15 homes received minor damage in Miami. ^In 2008, heavy rain associated with the remnants of Hurricane Ike caused the Illinois River near Watts, OK to moderately flood. The river rose above flood stage the night of the 14th and crested at 1am on the 15th at 17.1 feet.

In 1980, a tornado touched down 8 miles NNW of Coweta, OK. One house was destroyed  and several others were severely damaged. The roof was ripped off of a business 2 miles north of Coweta. Straight-line wind damage was reported in Vinita, where part of the roof was torn off a local radio station.

In 1908, lightning struck the powder house of the Samples Mining company near McAlester, OK in Pittsburg County. One person was killed, 10 others were seriously injured, and a dozen homes of miners were destroyed. 17 Katy box cars were also wrecked.

In 1894, a tornado struck the town of Jennings, OK in Pawnee County and the nearby small community of Mining. 3 people were killed and several others injured. In all about 50 homes were destroyed. ^In 1975, 8.56 inches of rain fell in 5 hours in Pryor, OK. The town received extensive flood damage, especially along Park Avenue. Pryor Creek also flooded south of town, closing some roads.

In 1993, severe thunderstorms developed in northeast OK during the afternoon and evening. Dime to quarter sized hail accompanied many of the storms, with golf ball sized hail 5.5 miles west of Bartlesville. 1 tornado (F0) also touched down briefly 4 miles east of Beggs near the intersection of U.S. Highway 75 and State Highway 16. A roof was blown off a mobile home, with other minor damage reported. Thunderstorm winds gusted to 60 miles an hour at Copan.
In 1938, Tulsa reached a record low temperature of 39 degrees. ^In 1954 Tulsa reached a record high temperature of 104.

In 2006, a tornado in Pushmataha County, OK produced minor damage to several homes and snapped trees. An F0 tornado touched down 3 miles SSW of Miller and another about 5 miles NW of Antlers. Tree damage was found south of the tornado paths, likely associated with strong wind gusts in the rear flank downdraft. Other damages included a barn that was destroyed and a house that received minor damage.

In 1970, severe thunderstorms produced a tornado in Morris, OK, which damaged several buildings. Straight line wind gusts to 100 mph were recorded near Muskogee. These strong winds destroyed a mobile home by moving it 50 feet. ^In 2006, severe thunderstorms moved across eastern OK and northwest AR in the evening to early morning hours of the 23rd. The storms produced widespread wind damage, with 70 mph winds reported in Cherokee, Sequoyah, and Wagoner Counties. The OK Mesonet site near Webbers Falls measured a 73 mph wind gust. Large hail from nickel to quarter size was also common, with golf ball sized hail in Wilburton, OK and Lincoln, AR.

In 1988, severe thunderstorms produced 4.5 inch hail near Enterprise, OK in Haskell County. Wind damage was also reported in Haskell County near Kinta, and at Indianola in Pittsburg County. ^In 2018, the remnants of Pacific Tropical Depression 19 along with a cold front brought heavy rainfall to much of eastern OK and western AR from the 21st -23rd. Widespread totals of 4 to 7 inches were observed, with localized amounts of 8 to 11 inches south of I-40 in southeast OK.

In 1973, a strong tornado damaged 8 farms in Craig and Ottawa Counties in northeast Oklahoma, and unroofed 7 homes. The tornado path was from northeast of Vinita in Craig County to southeast of Miami in Ottawa County. 14 people were injured. ^In 2019, tropical moisture associated with the remnants of Tropical Storm Imelda from the Atlantic, and Hurricane Lorena from the Pacific, brought several rounds of heavy rainfall to much of eastern OK and western AR between September 20th and 25th. Widespread 3 to 5 inch rainfall totals occurred, with some amounts near 10 inches over far southeast OK and near the OK/KS border. Reports of water rescues and numerous flooded roads were received from Benton, Washington AR, Muskogee, Tulsa, Craig, and Rogers Counties.

In 1993, heavy rain fell in northeast OK from the night of September 24th through the morning of September 25th, causing extensive flash flooding. Up to 8.5 inches of rain fell in extreme northeast OK, causing many creeks in Nowata, Craig, and Ottawa Counties to flood. About 150 people were evacuated from the area, mainly from near Tar Creek in Miami, OK. Some homes had 4 to 5 feet of flood waters. The Spring River near Quapaw crested at a record level of 46.40 feet on the 26th, which was 26.4 feet above flood stage.

In 1986, an F2 tornado touched down 3 miles south of Coweta, OK. 8 mobile homes, 2 houses, and a garage were damaged and several barns were destroyed. The damage was estimated at $100,000. An F0 tornado also touched down near 181st and Memorial in Bixby. ^In 1996, thunderstorms produced very heavy rainfall, resulting in widespread flash flooding across eastern OK and  northwest AR. 4 to 8 inches of rain was common throughout the area, resulting in several creeks and roads being flooded and closed. 4 fatalities were reported west of Tahlequah, OK when a car was swept off a low water crossing.

In 1942, Tulsa's coolest low temperature for the month of September was recorded at 35 degrees. ^In 1959, a large tornado touched down near Hollow, OK in Craig County and destroyed a motel. This same tornado caused F4 damage in Kansas near Oswego.

In 1915, severe thunderstorms moved through eastern OK. The new town of Kusa, OK east of Henryetta in Okmulgee County suffered considerable loss from a strong wind storm. The Esterie Smelter lost one block nearing completion. 2 frame store buildings were blown off of their foundations, while a 15 foot stone wall was demolished. Several homes were blown away.

In 1927, a tornado outbreak struck from eastern OK into the Mississippi Valley. 8 were people were injured near Checotah, OK in McIntosh County, while 20 people were injured near Rudy, AR in Crawford County. 5 of the injuries at Rudy were in a school building when a wall collapsed and some students fell from the second floor to the first. At least 10 homes in Rudy were destroyed with about 20 others damaged. The same outbreak produced a tornado that killed 79 people in St. Louis, MO.

In 1998, a strong cold front that moved south across eastern OK produced widespread thunderstorms. One thunderstorm that became severe was located in Creek and Okmulgee Counties. The storm produced 60-70 mph winds and hen egg size hail (2 inches) near Slick in SE Creek County. ^In 2011, A persistent ridge of high pressure continued to dominate the weather across the south central U.S. during September, resulting in prolonged dry weather. Most of eastern OK and northwest AR received below normal precipitation for the month. Large areas of Choctaw and Pushmataha Counties in southeast OK received as little as 5 to 25 percent of the average precipitation for the month. As a result, exceptional drought conditions continued across Okfuskee, Creek, and Pawnee Counties and developed across Choctaw County. Extreme drought conditions persisted across much of the remainder of southeast OK while severe drought conditions continued across the northeastern portion of the state.

In 1927, for the second time in 3 days, tornadoes hit eastern OK and northwest AR. 32 people were injured in the 'Mt. Olive' community in Haskell Co, OK and 7 were injured in Whitefield, OK where a church and several homes were destroyed. Gentry, AR in Benton County experienced a tornado after midnight, damaging a few homes.

In 1959, flooding occurred in northeastern Oklahoma. Heavy rain fell from October 1st to the 4th, producing 10 to 12 inches of rain in some areas. ^In 1995, isolated severe thunderstorms developed in eastern Oklahoma, producing dime size hail at Vernon (McIntosh Co)and at Keota (Haskell Co). Later that afternoon, storms redeveloped and produced dime size hail in Akins (Sequoyah Co) and near Hodgen (LeFlore Co).

In 1926, severe flooding occurred on the Caney River in Bartlesville, OK in Washington County. 2 people were killed and at least 1,500 people were left homeless. ^In 1983, two microbursts and a small F0 tornado occurred in Broken Arrow, OK. The high school was damaged and the band building was destroyed, causing $1 million in damages. ^In 2007, Thunderstorms developed across west central AR ahead of a slow-moving cold front during the afternoon. Five to seven inches of rain fell in northern Sebastian County resulting in significant flash flooding. The Ft. Smith ASOS recorded about 6.5 inches of rainfall during the event. In Greenwood, water entered 80 homes and several businesses. 28 homes were severely damaged.

In 1998, Oklahoma experienced its worst-ever October tornado outbreak. At least 22 tornadoes occurred in OK (7 in northeast OK). The most significant tornado in eastern OK was an F2 that traveled along a 27 mile path from Okfuskee County to Okmulgee County.  In the small community of IXL (Okfuskee Co), nearly every structure sustained at least some damage. A house, 2 mobile homes, 4 businesses and a public building at the IXL Park were destroyed. In Haydenville (Okfuskee Co), 2 single-family houses and a mobile home were destroyed. The Haydenville Fire Station also sustained major damage. 4 people inside the mobile home were injured, one of them critically. A survey showed that the damage path was at times 3 miles wide, likely indicating there were several smaller tornadoes circulating around the larger tornado.

In 1959, the Arkansas River in Tulsa, OK crested at 22.0 feet, the 3rd in highest crest level in history. ^In 1986, torrential rainfall occurred from the remnants of Hurricane Paine across north central OK and southern KS. A record crest of 27.7 feet was recorded on the Caney River at Bartlesville, where about 800 homes were under water, some up to their roofs, and water covered almost one-third of the city. Severe flooding along the Neosho River at Miami, OK (Ottawa Co) forced the evacuation of about 500 families. The Arkansas River crested at 25.21 feet in Tulsa, which is the highest crest level in Tulsa history. Flood damage was mostly limited to river parks and industrial areas in Tulsa. ^In 1998, flash flooding occurred as a result of the storms associated with the previous night's tornado outbreak. The supercells from the night before grew into a line of thunderstorms, that remained nearly stationary roughly along I-44 through very early morning. Widespread rainfall amounts of 5 to 7 inches were common along the I-44 corridor. Significant flash floods occurred in Sapulpa (Creek Co), where several homes were evacuated.

In 2002, lightning struck the police station in Grove, OK in Delaware County as well as a nearby house. The lightning caused $10,000 in damage to the police station and $40,000 in damage to the house because the lightning strike caught it on fire. ^In 2019, heavy rain fell across parts of northeast OK and much of northwest AR from October 5th through 7th as several rounds of showers and thunderstorms developed north of a stalled front. A large area of far northeast OK and northwest AR received 5 to 8 inches of rain, with portions of Delaware, Benton, Washington AR, and Carroll Counties receiving 8 to 13 inches. Widespread flash flooding occurred in Benton and Washington Counties in northwest AR. Numerous roads were closed due to high water and several swift water rescues were needed.

In 1992, severe thunderstorms moved into eastern Oklahoma late in the afternoon. Strong winds on Kerr Lake sank a tug boat and 8 of its barges. Strong winds were also located in Creek, Pawnee, and Osage Counties. ^In 1994, severe thunderstorms developed in northeast Oklahoma, producing strong winds up to 74 mph. Some areas, such as Bartlesville, received quarter size hail, and nickel size hail fell in Lenapah. ^In 2012, The low temperature at Tulsa dipped to 32 degrees...the earliest such occurrence on record in Tulsa.

In 1970, a tornado traveled from 3 miles north of Siloam Springs to 2 miles north of Gentry. 4 people were injured and a house, motel, and mobile home received significant damage. ^In 2009, a very moist and unstable air mass spread across the Southern Plains and Ozarks ahead of a strong cold front. Northwest AR and parts of east central OK received heavy rainfall amounts of 2 to 5 inches with up to 7 inches in some areas. Strong thunderstorm wind gusts to 88 mph were measured by storm spotters in Ozark. The wind damaged power poles, a slaughter house, trees, and homes. The heavy rainfall caused significant flooding, with damage to homes and a number of road closures and multiple water rescues of stranded motorists.

In 1914, a large tornado touched down near Commerce, OK in Ottawa County and destroyed 4 homes. There were about a dozen injuries, and the same twister later killed 6 people in Cherokee County, Kansas. ^In 2018, Severe thunderstorms moved across eastern OK during the late morning and early afternoon, producing damaging wind gusts in several locations. A few homes suffered roof damage in Mayes and Rogers counties.

In 1969, severe thunderstorms developed in eastern OK and northwest AR. Wind damage occurred in Warner (Muskogee Co), and the Webbers Falls (Muskogee Co) High School was damaged. The gym roof at Connors State College in Warner was blown off, and a grain bin was blown across the highway east of Warner. Winds also destroyed one and significantly damaged another home near Jenny Lind, AR (Sebastian Co).

In 1969, 2 days of heavy rainfall resulted in amounts of 4 to 11 inches. This caused flooding of several rivers in eastern Oklahoma. Homes were flooded in Henryetta (Okmulgee Co) and wind damage was reported in Hugo, OK (Choctaw Co). ^In 1973, the state rainfall record in a 24-hour period was established with 15.68 inches in Enid, Oklahoma.

In 2011, thunderstorms developed along and ahead of a cold front moving through the region during the early evening hours. Instability and low level wind shear were marginal for long-lived, organized severe storms but the stronger storms produced large hail and a brief tornado 2 miles northwest of Berryville, AR (Carroll Co).

In 1981, heavy rains from the 11th through the 15th caused flooding across southeast OK. McAlester, OK received 8 inches of rain (17.4 inches for the month) and 8-10 inches were common from McAlester to the southwest. An F1 tornado also touched down near Unger, OK (Choctaw Co). ^In 2012, Severe thunderstorms developed during the afternoon over central OK ahead of a cold front and moved into eastern OK and northwest AR during the late afternoon and evening.  There were several reports of damaging wind, one brief tornado in Benton County, Arkansas.  In addition to the severe weather, 2 to 4 inches of rain fell over portions of Creek, Tulsa, and Rogers Counties, with as much as 4.60 inches at Oilton, OK. Sadly, a young teenager drowned when he and his friends were playing near a swollen creek in Tulsa.

In 1985,10 to 12 inches of rain fell across southern  Wagoner County in a 48-hour period. Many roads and several bridges were washed out, stranding at least a dozen families in rural areas. The floods caused $1.25 million in damages. Floods also occurred on Buckeye Creek in and around Okemah, OK in Okfuskee County.
In 2003, severe thunderstorms moved through northwest Arkansas. Gentry received thunderstorm winds estimated in excess of 70 mph. Damages included the roof of a church that was ripped off.

In 1984, an F2 tornado struck along a path from Dora to Cedarville in Crawford County, AR. There was heavy damage at Cedarville Elementary School, the high school, and several farm buildings. An F1 tornado hit Summers in Washington Co, AR, damaging a mobile home. Another F1 tornado passed from Strickler to 5 miles NE of West Fork in Washington Co, AR, damaging 15 houses and 40 farm buildings. Finally, an F2 tornado touched down near Roland, destroying one home. Straight-line wind damage to several roofs and outbuildings occurred in Westville, OK (Adair Co). Total damage was over $200 thousand.

In 2007, strong straight line winds caused at least one large tent to collapse at Oktoberfest near downtown Tulsa. At least 55 people were injured and a peak gust of wind was measured at 85 mph at the Tulsa International Airport. Other areas of northeast OK and northwest AR received wind damage from wind gusts of 70-90 mph.
In 1998, northeast Oklahoma received flooding from October 18th to the 20th. The Neosho River at Commerce, OK rose to 17.0 feet the morning of the 19th. The flood stage was 15 feet.

In 2005, Tulsa set a record high of 91 degrees, the third consecutive day of 90 degree weather. ^In 2015, 'flash' drought conditions continued to worsen in southeast OK, with a portion of Choctaw County upgraded to severe drought conditions. Significant rainfall at the end of the month and through November once again eliminated the drought.

In 1984, significant flooding occurred in southeast OK. 13 inches of rain fell in 24 hours in Clayton, OK, causing extensive flooding as Rock Creek overflowed. Most of the town received damage. 10 to 14 inches of rain fell elsewhere in Pushmataha County, OK, causing widespread flooding and destroying 5 bridges. In Latimer Co., 5 bridges were destroyed near Red Oak and 7 more were destroyed near Buffalo Valley. Total damages associated with the flooding was near a half million dollars. ^In 2019, severe thunderstorms moved across eastern OK and western AR during the late evening of the 20th and early morning of the 21st. Five tornadoes were confirmed, including a long-tracked EF-2 tornado in Benton Co that caused considerable damage northeast of Siloam Springs and in the Pinnacle Hills area of Rogers. Four of the tornadoes occurred in OK, which brought the statewide total for 2019 to 146; a new record for most OK tornadoes in a year.

In 1979, severe thunderstorms produced strong winds, causing widespread wind damage in northeast Oklahoma. In Terlton (Pawnee Co), one mobile home was destroyed and another received significant damage. In Jennings (Pawnee Co), one mobile home was destroyed and 2 people were injured. 90 mph gusts were measured in Dewey and Bartlesville (Washington Co). About 300 homes were damaged, 9 mobile homes were severely damaged, 35 businesses were damaged, and 1 person was injured in Dewey. An estimated 100 mph gust was reported north of Collinsville (Tulsa Co), damaging a few homes and injuring 3 people.

In 2011, an unstable atmosphere in the afternoon allowed thunderstorms to initiate in the evening. The storms moved east and southeast into northeastern OK, producing strong winds and hail. Supercells moved through Okfuskee, McIntosh, Pittsburg, and Okmulgee Counties with up to softball size hail and widespread wind damage from the wind-driven hail. The hail damaged windows, automobiles, homes, and trees. The wind-driven hail even stripped the bark from some trees. The storms later evolved into a squall line which brought more storms across portions of southeast OK.

In 1983, the remnants of Hurricane Tico brought widespread torrential rainfall from October 17th to the 23rd. Large areas of northeast Oklahoma received 5 to 7 inches of rainfall, with 8 to 15 inches common in an area southwest of Tulsa. While some flash flooding and property damage occurred, widespread river flooding was likely prevented by drought conditions from the preceding summer.

In 1991, several clusters of severe thunderstorms moved across eastern OK. Four small F0 tornadoes occurred: between Kinta and Lequire (Haskell Co), northeast of Collinsville (Tulsa Co), 2 miles southeast of Checotah (McIntosh Co), and 2 miles east of Rentiesville (McIntosh Co). The tornado near Checotah destroyed the wood frame of a house, a mobile home, and 3 barns. A semi was also flipped by strong wind on I-40 near Checotah. The other tornadoes caused little or no damage.

In 1997, severe thunderstorms developed in eastern OK during the early afternoon, producing strong winds, hail, and an F0 tornado. Winds damaged several power poles, homes, automobiles, and the Haskell County Sheriff's Office near Whitefield, OK, costing $350,000. An 18 wheeler was blown off U.S. Highway 69 by strong winds 5 miles east of Wainwright (Muskogee Co). Golfball size hail fell in Muskogee and dime to quarter size hail fell in Wilburton (Latimer Co). A small F0 tornado touched down briefly near Hackett, AR (Sebastian Co.)but did not cause significant damage.

In 1995, severe thunderstorms developed in northeast OK during the early evening. The storms produced 4 tornadoes, large hail, and damaging winds. 18 houses, 4 mobile homes, and 2 businesses were damaged in Woodall, OK in Cherokee County. Several barns were also damaged, and the total cost was about $200,000. Severe thunderstorms also moved across northwest AR during the evening. Strong winds overturned a small outbuilding and tore down trees west of Bentonville (Benton Co).

In 1991, severe thunderstorms developed in the late evening and continued into early the next morning. The storms produced 3 tornadoes. An F1 tornado touched down 3 miles west of Westville, OK (Adair Co) around 4:15 am and overturned a mobile home and damaged the roofs of several homes near Chance, OK (Adair Co). Another twister caused minor damage at Moseley school in Delaware County, while an F1 tornado damaged several homes 5 miles east of Colcord, OK (Delaware Co). Several hangars were damaged or destroyed at the Wagoner Airport in Wagoner Co, costing $50,000 in damages. A number of businesses in McAlester, OK (Pittsburg Co) had windows blown out.
In 1896, a tornado moved through rural Pittsburg County, OK, killing 2 people near Hartshorne.

In 1942, a violent tornado struck the north side of Berryville, Arkansas in Carroll County around 10:30 pm. About 140 buildings were destroyed and many homes were swept away. There were 29 fatalities and over 100 injuries. The fatalities occurred in 13 different homes. About 600 people were left homeless. ^In 1993, 0.3 inches of snow were officially measured at both Tulsa and Fayetteville...the earliest measurable snowfall on record for both locations.

In 1979, severe thunderstorms caused wind damage through much of northwest AR and southeast OK. Wind damage occurred in Cecil (Franklin Co), Crosses (Madison Co), Blue Eye (Carroll Co), and West Fork (Washington Co). Total damage was estimated around $175,000. The same storm system was causing severe blizzard conditions in the Oklahoma panhandle at the same time. ^In 2019, very light snow fell across northeast OK and northwest AR. While little if any accumulation occurred, this was only the 5th time snow has been observed in Tulsa in October and only the 6th time at Fayetteville.

In 1992, severe thunderstorms developed in eastern Oklahoma in the afternoon. Wind gusts to 65 mph caused major roof damage to Quinton High School in Pittsburg Co and damaged a church and numerous homes. Additional severe storms later in the evening produced dime to golf ball size hail in Tulsa, along with wind damage in Pryor, OK (Mayes Co) and Commerce, OK (Ottawa Co). ^In 1999, unusual east-to-west moving thunderstorms spawned 4 tornadoes (all F0) in Creek County.

In 1972, heavy rain over far southeast OK from October 31st to November 1st caused flooding along the Glover and Little Rivers. 6 to 8 inches of rain fell in Antlers (Pushmataha Co) and Hugo (Choctaw Co). The flooding closed many roads and stranded livestock. ^In 2004, heavy thunderstorm rain caused flooding of roads across Benton County, AR. The NW Arkansas Regional Airport received 4.04 inches of rain during the event. Severe flooding occurred in Muskogee, and the Emergency Operation Center had to be evacuated when 6 inches of water flooded it.

In 1991, an early winter storm with light snow covered northeast Oklahoma. Highway 75 in Okmulgee County was nearly impassable for several hours. Many areas received record low temperatures. Tulsa's record for lowest high temperature for this day occurred during this snow storm. The high temperature was 27 degrees.

In 1959, heavy rain in the evening caused flooding near Dewar, OK (Okmulgee Co), Broken Arrow (Tulsa Co), and along the Illinois River near Scraper, OK (Cherokee Co). ^In 1974, a tornado 2 miles west of Bartlesville, OK (Washington Co) in the pre-dawn hours destroyed 3 barns and 2 garages, and damaged one house. The early morning storms caused flooding in Benton County, AR, killing one person at a low water bridge on Little Flint Creek. Additional storms that evening produced another tornado in Pittsburg County, OK, which caused damage at the Union Stockyards and destroyed a barn near McAlester before moving northeast into Krebs. There, the twister destroyed 3 buildings and damaged 12 other buildings and 20-30 homes. .

In 1922, a violent tornado tracked from near Shamrock, OK in Creek County to north of Mannford in Pawnee County, killing 11 people and injuring 40. About 30 homes and at least 130 oil rigs were destroyed. About 30 homes of oil field workers were also destroyed near Drumright in Creek County. 9 of the fatalities were in the Drumright/Shamrock area.

In 2008, severe thunderstorms with large hail and damaging winds affected northeast Oklahoma from the late afternoon to the early morning of the 6th. A weak tornado in Osage Co destroyed a mobile home, damaged another mobile home, damaged the roof of a house, blew the roof off of a storage building, and damaged a number of trees. Two people in the mobile home that was destroyed were injured. ^In 2011 a record breaking 5.6 magnitude earthquake struck Oklahoma late in the evening. The epicenter was 4 miles east of Sparks, OK in Lincoln County and could be felt as far away as Illinois and Tennessee.

In 1996, severe thunderstorms developed over eastern Oklahoma during the evening and continued into the morning of the 7th. The storms produced widespread rainfall of 3 to 6 inches across portions of northwest Arkansas and eastern Oklahoma, which resulted in flash flooding.

In 2011, severe thunderstorms developed along a cold front approaching eastern Oklahoma in the early evening. The storms organized into a squall line and the stronger storms among the line produced hail. Bigheart in Osage County received 0.88 inch hail and Terlton in Pawnee County received 1 inch hail.

In 2000, a strong upper level storm system moved across southeast OK, producing a large swath of precipitation over eastern OK. The precipitation first fell as rain and changed to snow later in the evening. As much as 4 inches of snow fell in a narrow band across parts of Washington, Tulsa, Rogers, and Nowata Counties. The largest amount of snowfall reported was 7 inches 2 miles northwest of Owasso. ^In 2015, Fayetteville, AR saw its first autumn freeze on the 8th, ending the longest growing season on record for Fayetteville at 217 days (records began in 1950). The previous record was 214 days from March 31 to November 1, 1991.

In 1998, severe thunderstorms moved through eastern Oklahoma and west-central Arkansas. The line of storms produced strong gusts up to 80 mph. One supercell produced an F1 tornado in Fort Smith and later produced an F0 farther east in Franklin County. Another F1 tornado moved from extreme eastern OK into western AR near Fort Smith. The tornado caused damage to several homes and businesses. The most damage occurred at the Fort Smith Regional Airport, where several planes were damaged.

In 1995, after high temperatures in the lower 80s, a strong cold front brought severe thunderstorms followed by snow to much of northeast OK and northwest AR. Tulsa tied a record high of 83 degrees then received a daily record 1.8 inches of snow before midnight, which is phenomenal! 2 to 4 inches of snow fell from east-central OK into northwest AR by early the next morning.

In 1911, a strong arctic cold front known as the 'Great Blue Norther of 1911', plunged through the central U.S. and brought temperature changes of 60-75 degrees in a 24 hour period. Many locations through the plains, including Oklahoma City, OK and Springfield, MO observed daily record highs in the afternoon, only to reach record lows by midnight as temperatures plummeted from the mid 80s into the teens! ^In 1969, severe thunderstorms moved through northeast Oklahoma. Small hail was several inches deep from northern Creek County to northern Muskogee County. Golf ball size hail fell in Tulsa, Broken Arrow, and Muskogee, causing minor damage. ^In 2015, a strong low pressure system pushed a dry line through eastern OK, with sustained winds of 15-30 mph and gusts of 40 to 50 mph much of the day. These winds, combined with the low relative humidity, led to several large fires. Approximately 40,000 acres burned across Osage, Washington, and Nowata Counties, and the fires burned two residences and several barns and outbuildings.

In 1911, morning low temperatures fell into the single digits and teens across eastern OK and northwest AR, just one day after record high temperatures in the 80s were observed. ^In 2018, much of northeast OK and northwest AR received 1 to 2 inches of snow, with isolated amounts close to 3 inches.

In 1985, severe thunderstorms produced baseball size hail and 60 mph winds in Tulsa, OK. An F1 tornado also touched down in Broken Arrow, OK, where a school was damaged and 5 people were injured. Wind damage was also reported east of Claremore, OK (Rogers Co) and a school was damaged in Jay, OK (Delaware Co). Total damage was around $175,000.

In 2005, thunderstorms over northeast OK and northwest AR brought strong winds and large hail. In Fort Smith, AR a woman was struck by lightning and sent to a hospital for treatment. In northeast Oklahoma, several locations such as Vinita (Craig County), Mayes County, Skiatook (Osage, Tulsa County), and Oolagah (Rogers County) received penny and nickel size hail. Golfball size hail fell in Skiatook (Tulsa County), causing considerable damage. Thunderstorm winds in Vinita damaged a Sonic restaurant's awning.

In 1987, an F2 tornado hit 1 mile northwest of Vinita, OK (Craig Co). One house and several outbuildings were damaged, costing $45,000. Wind damage was also reported near Bernice, OK (Delaware Co) where 3 mobile homes on Grand Lake were destroyed.  1 person was injured, ^In 1988, severe thunderstorms caused wind damage in Tulsa. The storms also produced an F0 tornado in McCurtain (Haskell County) and damaging downburst wind nearby. 3 mobile homes and a shop building were destroyed, and 15 houses and a church were damaged.

In 1892, a tornado passed through Washington County, Arkansas southeast of Fayetteville. Four people were injured during this event. ^In 1963, strong winds gusting up to 50 mph caused some damage in northeast Oklahoma. Damage was reported in Tulsa and Henryetta (Okmulgee Co). A large wildfire also broke out near Barndall (Osage Co).

In 1958, a tornado hit 2 farms east of Lenapah, OK in Nowata County in the early morning, destroying a barn and 2 outbuildings. A 2x4 was flung into a house and barely missed a sleeping man. At least 15 other tornadoes were reported in Oklahoma, Arkansas, Texas, and Missouri. ^In 2015, a squall line moved across eastern OK and northwest AR during the morning. The storms produced strong winds across northeast OK, including a 99 mph gust at Red Rock (immediately west of the CWA boundary), and a 63 mph gust at Copan, OK (Washington Co). An EF-1 tornado damaged homes, outbuildings, trees, and power lines near Checotah, OK (McIntosh Co). ^In 2016, unseasonably warm temperatures, strong gusty wind, low relative humidity, and very dry vegetation promoted the rapid spread of several wildfires in northwestern Arkansas and northeast Oklahoma. The largest was in Franklin County near Cecil and Charleston. That fire burned about 1000 acres, destroyed a home and five outbuildings, and threatened another two dozen structures. The fire was contained on the 18th.

In 1985, flash flooding broke out in northeast Oklahoma and northwest Arkansas. In Benton Co, the War Eagle Mill was flooded up to 7 feet deep inside the building, causing $50,000 in damages. Many roads were flooded in northwest AR, and at least 62 people had to seek shelter in Washington Co. Several homes were also evacuated in Adair County, OK as the Barron Fork River reached its highest level since 1944. ^In 2003, a significant hail storm struck Tulsa county, with up to baseball sized hail reported in mid-town Tulsa, At least $20 million in damage was done mainly to cars and roofs. The hail covered the ground up to several inches deep in some places.

In 1970, a tornado tracked 20 miles across Washington Co, AR from south of Summers AR to just south of Tontitown. The most significant damage was just north of Lincoln and Prairie Grove, where 2 farms were severely damaged and 1 person was injured. A second tornado touched down southeast of Siloam Springs, AR (Benton Co), destroying 2 mobile homes and causing minor damage in East Gate addition. Straight-line wind damage occurred in Bella Vista and Hiwasse (Benton Co). ^In 1975, a line of severe storms with a cold front caused many reports of wind damage.

In 1979, Bartlesville, OK received 4-6 inches of rain, causing significant damage from flash flooding. ^In 1994, a strong low pressure system moved across Kansas and produced strong gradient winds in northeast OK and northwest AR. The strong winds caused widespread wind damage. Power lines were blown down in Dewey (Washington Co), 6-12 inch diameter tree limbs were blown down in Bristow (Creek Co), and a roof was blown off in Muldrow (Sequoyah Co). Wind gusts to 63 mph were observed 2 miles northwest of Tulsa, and at Henryetta (Okmulgee Co). Winds up to 60 miles an hour downed trees and power lines in Bella Vista, AR (Benton Co) and strong winds blew down 2 sheds in Decatur, AR (Benton Co).

In 1972, consecutive snowstorms on November 17th-18th, then on the 20th-21st brought several inches of snow over parts of north-central and northeast OK. Foraker in Osage Co received the most snow with 8 inches. ^In 2011, widespread heavy rains fell across southeast OK and caused flash flooding. Residents in the area reported many low water crossings under water around and northeast of Nashoba (Pushmataha Co). Cripple Creek was out of its banks west of Nashoba. Several rural roads were  impassable between Clayton and Nashoba. The Kiamichi River near Clayton rose above its flood stage of 17 feet early on the 22nd and crested at 19.65 feet on the 23rd, resulting in moderate flooding. ^In 2015 Tulsa, OK saw its first autumn freeze, ending the longest growing season on record at 259 days from March 6 to November 21, 2015 (records began in 1906). The previous record was 257 days from March 6 to November 19, 1985.

In 1983, several tornadoes struck southeast OK in the afternoon. An F2 tornado hit 3 miles northeast of Soper in Choctaw County, damaging 2 barns and several houses, while another F2 hit 3 miles west of Nashoba in Pushmataha County. An F3 tornado hit Pushmataha County in Albion, damaging many of the buildings in town and injuring 3 people, and two other F3 tornadoes touched down in LeFlore County. One of these tornadoes struck near Wister and Poteau, injuring 6 people and causing significant damage. Total damage was at least $2 million. ^In 1999, severe thunderstorms produced heavy rain and 5 tornadoes in northeast OK. A tornado southeast of Claremore (Rogers Co) destroyed one mobile home was and blew another off its foundation. A house under construction was flattened and three horse barns were heavily damaged.

In 1908, a tornado killed 14 people and injured 40 in Franklin County, AR with heavy damage in Mulberry Township, Jethro, Cravens, and Watlula Township. Another small tornado caused minor damage in Carroll County. ^In 1973, eastern OK received 2-5 inches of rain on the 23rd, and 2-6 more inches of rain the following day. The heavy rainfall caused dangerous flash flooding. The flash flooding resulted in 1 death, 1 injury, and millions of dollars in damages ($400K in Cherokee County alone). Severe thunderstorms also produced tennis ball size hail in Muskogee, and a tornado damaged several homes in Pryor (Mayes Co). ^In 2001, storms in northwest AR produced a few F1 tornadoes in Franklin Co, causing several structures to be damaged or destroyed. damage occurred near Wiederkehr Village, Etna, Denning and Ozark.

In 1987, flash flooding caused 20 families to be evacuated from their homes in Miami, OK. ^In 1996, freezing rain and sleet fell across northeast OK and northwest AR. 2-4 inches of sleet fell from Fayetteville to Berryville in AR and McAlester to Westville in OK, causing several traffic accidents and power outages. Flash flooding also occurred due to thunderstorms in LeFlore County, OK. The Hodgens and Heavener areas experienced flooded roads.
In 1944, a tornado hit the eastern edge of Collinsville, OK in Tulsa County. 25 homes were damaged or destroyed and 5 people were injured.

In 1965, northeast Oklahoma received 50-60 mph gusts. Several wildfires broke out, burning thousands of acres of land. Two homes and several barns were destroyed. Most of the fires occurred in Rogers, Nowata, Muskogee, and Okmulgee Counties.

In 1919, sleet and freezing rain across Oklahoma accumulated to greater than one inch. The ice fell from November 27-29. ^In 1990, severe thunderstorms caused wind damage in Creek, Rogers, Muskogee, LeFlore, and Benton Counties in the early morning. ^In 2005, damaging winds and low dewpoint temperatures behind a dry line in eastern OK brought gusts of 60-70 mph across much of northeastern OK. The strong winds downed several power lines and accompanied with low humidity and dry conditions, wildfires broke out. About 35,000 acres were burned in eastern OK.

In 1986, ice fog occurred in parts of northeastern OK. Visibility was reduced to 10 feet near Claremore, OK. The low visibility caused a 10 car pile-up on U.S. Highway 66 bridge. ^In 2001, an ice storm occurred in northwest AR. Ice accumulations of 1/2 to 1 inch were found in Benton, Carroll, Washington, and Madison Counties. Ice also accumulated in Adair County, OK. The ice brought down trees and utility lines/poles. ^In 2015, multiple rounds of heavy rainfall affected eastern OK and western AR from the 27th through the 30th. The 4-day rainfall totals ranged from 2.5 inches near Ponca City to nearly 10 inches along the Red River.  Most of eastern OK and northwest AR received 3 to 5 inches of rain from this event, while 5 to 10 inch amounts affected much of southeast OK.  The heavy rain resulted in numerous road closures throughout eastern OK and northwest AR, and there were several swift water rescues.

In 1991, severe thunderstorms in west-central AR and eastern OK produced strong wind and hail. Fort Smith received wind and hail damage. Almost grapefruit size hail fell in Crawford County, and walnut size hail fell 5 miles south of Mannford, OK (Creek Co.). The roofs were blown off of 8 homes in Adair Co., OK, while wind damage in Van Buren, AR (Crawford Co.) was estimated at $50,000.

In 1985, widespread freezing rain, freezing drizzle, and ice pellets fell across northeast OK. Severe thunderstorms producing 90 mph wind didn't make matters better. The wind damaged a house, mobile home, and some barns in Pittsburg and Blanco in Pittsburg County, resulting in about $250,000 in damages. ^In 2006, 10 to 14 inches of snow fell on much of the area north of I-44, with blizzard conditions in the afternoon. A record was broken in Tulsa this day when 10.4 inches of snow fell in a single day. ^In 2015, eastern OK and western AR saw one of its wettest Novembers on record, as most area received between 150 and 300 percent of normal monthly rain. The northeast OK climate division broke its record for wettest November, while southeast and east central OK saw their 2nd and 3rd wettest November, respectively. ^In 2018, a line of severe thunderstorms produced damaging winds and several tornadoes over eastern OK and west central AR during the evening. A long-tracked EF-2 tornado caused damage along a 47 mile path from Sequoyah Co. into Delaware Co., injuring 5 people, damaging numerous homes, and destroying boat docks on Tenkiller Lake.

In 2004, the Poteau River near Panama rose above its flood stage of 29 feet on November 30th. The river crested on December 1st at 32.20 feet. The river fell below its flood stage the following day, and only minor flooding occurred to some agricultural land.

In 1982, an F2 tornado hit Alma in Crawford County, AR. 10 houses were destroyed and 8 were severely damaged. The same system was responsible for widespread floods in Arkansas and several other tornadoes. ^In 1999, severe thunderstorms moved across eastern OK and western AR. A gustnado occurred at about 1am in Fort Smith and was only on the ground for about 20 seconds. 3 warehouses and 2 office buildings were heavily damaged. A few other structures were damaged, including a hangar at the Fort Smith airport.

In 1902, a major snowstorm on Dec 3-4 dumped 16.6 inches of snow in Fayetteville and 8 inches in Ft. Smith. ^In 1908, a tornado touched down near Westville, OK in Adair County. Three homes were destroyed and a large number of cattle were killed.

In 1984, 5-8 inches of snow fell in northeast OK, with up to 10 inches in Skiatook. 3-5 inches of snow fell in northwest AR. The heavy snow in Tulsa caused numerous trees and power lines to go down. ^In 2002, an ice storm affected northeast OK and northwest AR from December 3-4. Ice formed on trees and power lines, resulting in 14,400 homes and businesses to lose power in Arkansas, plus 6,000 homes in Sand Springs, OK and Bartlesville, OK.  Many roads became slick and hazardous, forcing schools to close on the 4th.

In 1975, a strong F3 tornado hit eastern Tulsa, injuring 38 people, destroying 29 apartments, and damaging over 200 structures. 20 aircraft were destroyed and 20 more were damaged at a small airport. Another F3 tornado traveled from Okmulgee to Coweta in Wagoner County, and F2 tornadoes were reported near Bixby, OK in Tulsa County and Wilburton in Latimer County. The tornado in Wilburton caused damage to Eastern Oklahoma State College, and 3 basketball players were injured by flying glass in the gym.

In 1998, low pressure developed along a cold front, bringing the area unseasonably warm air. This caused isolated thunderstorms in northeast OK, producing strong winds. Thunderstorm wind gusted to 52 mph in Eucha (Delaware County)^In 2004, thunderstorm winds gusted at 60 mph 5 miles north of Eufaula in Mcintosh County, OK. The winds blew down large tree limbs. ^In 2013, a significant winter storm struck eastern Oklahoma and western Arkansas, with 5-8 inch snow accumulation roughly impacting areas south of I-44 and north of I-40, with as much as 12 inches near Pea Ridge, AR (Benton Co). Ice accumulations of over 1 inch from Hugo to Antlers, Poteau, and toward Greenwood and Ozark resulted in widespread power outages.

In 1966, unseasonably warm weather resulted in record high temperatures of 81 degrees at Fort Smith and 80 degrees at Tulsa, which remains tied for the warmest December temperature on record. ^In 2006, December began with severe to extreme drought conditions in much of northeastern Oklahoma. By the end of December, drought conditions were reduced to below severe due to above normal precipitation amounts.

In 1963, strong wind allowed several large wildfires to ignite. There were fires near Boley, and several hundred acres between Wynona-Barnsdall were burned. ^In 2008, an F1 tornado was produced near Broken Arrow, severely damaging a mobile home and destroying a shed.

In 2003, a band of moderate to heavy snow developed from northern Osage County through western and southern Tulsa County. Heaviest snow amounts included 9.5 inches near Hominy, 8 inches in Jenks, 7 inches in Foraker, and 6 inches in Pawhuska and Bixby. ^In 2007, one of the most destructive ice storms in the state's history struck northeast OK, and a small portion of northwest AR, from the 9th through the 10th. One to two inches of ice accumulated over a roughly 40 mile wide area along the I-44 corridor, causing widespread power outages for about 1 million people, some of whom were without power for a few weeks. Total damage was estimated around 600 million dollars.

In 1971, heavy rainfall occurred in southeast Oklahoma. Up to 10 inches fell in far southeast OK in 24 hours. 11.34 inches fell at Bear Mountain Tower, OK. This was the heaviest rainfall in at least 30 years.
In 1965, severe thunderstorms during the evening produced 1 to 2 inch diameter hail in Fort Smith and Van Buren, Arkansas.

In 2000, a strong winter storm developed over the Southern Plains and produced snow, sleet, and freezing rain. Northeast OK and northwest AR mainly received snow, with 8-12 inches north of Highway 412, including up to 16 inches in Big Cabin, OK in Craig Co. East central OK and west central AR received a mix of sleet and freezing rain, while southeast OK received significant ice. Pushmataha and Choctaw Counties reported that 5,000 customers were without power. ^In 2003, an upper level system produced a band of heavy snowfall in northeast OK, mainly north and west of the Tulsa area. Up to 10 inches of snow fell in Pawhuska.

In 1967, an ice storm affected northeast OK. While the worst impacts with this storm were across western OK, many areas north of I-40 in eastern OK saw up to a half inch of ice accumulation. ^In 1987, the northwest half of OK received heavy snow from December 13-15. 4 to 6 inches were common over northeast OK, with up to 10 inches in Osage and Pawnee counties. 1 to 4 inches of snow were recorded from east central OK into northwest AR.

In 1989, Arctic air plunged south over the area and persisted for several days. Wind chill temperatures sunk as low as  -30 to -50 degrees as the initial blast of cold air arrived! Tulsa broke or tied record lows on the 15th and 16th, and from the 21st through the 23rd. The lows of -8 in Tulsa and -5 in Fort Smith on the 23rd remain the coldest ever for December at both locations.

In 1992, heavy rain fell from December 13-15. Two to five inches of rain fell in eastern Oklahoma, bringing widespread flash floods. Many creeks overflowed their banks and caused several road closings. One car was swept away near Okay, OK in Wagoner County. The driver was rescued by a fire fighter who swam out to the car. The next evening, a woman and her son were rescued from a creek in Ottawa County. With these accidents, you can see that it is important to 'Turn around, don't drown!'

In 2001, heavy thunderstorms caused widespread flash flooding. Madison County, AR had several roads flooded, and a few roads and bridges were washed out. Northwest AR and southeast OK experienced numerous road closures. A few homes were also flooded in Big Cedar, OK in LeFlore County, and minor flooding occurred on the Poteau and Illinois Rivers from the 16th through the 18th.
In 1929, a tornado destroyed the city pump house in Fort Smith. The same structure had been damaged by another twister several months earlier on May 1, 1929.
In 1968, a tornado traveled across Skiatook, OK in Tulsa County early in the afternoon, damaging 3 homes in town. Another tornado touched down in northern Pittsburg County.

In 1983, the area experienced one of the worst cold snaps on record from mid to late December. The 15th through the 30th was one of the coldest 2 week periods in history. Temperatures were below freezing almost the entire period, reaching below or nearly below zero several nights. Wind chills of -40 to -60 degrees were observed along with periods of light snow and freezing rain. The extreme cold caused widespread damage to water pipes, and many people were without power for several days. ^In 2012, a line of strong to severe thunderstorms moved across southeast OK and western AR during the evening. A short lived EF1 tornado moved over a 3 mile path in far Northeastern Sebastian Co., AR, damaging a permanent home, a couple of mobile homes and a rural fire station. The ASOS at Fort Smith Regional Airport recorded a peak gust to 63 mph.

In 1990, all of the area except southeast OK experienced an ice storm. A thunderstorm with ice pellets, freezing rain, and 1/2 inch hail hit Pittsburg County, OK. The ice storm caused numerous traffic accidents and several fatalities.

In 1967, an early morning F2 tornado touched down in Sebastian County, AR, on the southeast side of Fort Smith. The twister injured 6 people. This tornado was part of a large outbreak that affected the mid and upper Mississippi Valley. ^In 2013, an ice storm impacted a large portion of northeast Oklahoma and extreme northwest Arkansas. Some areas along and just south of I-44 saw ice accumulations of 0.5-0.75 inches, which resulted in numerous power outages.

In 1966, a winter storm occurred in northeast OK on the 22nd and 23rd. 5 to 9 inches of snow fell in Osage and Ottawa Counties, with 11 inches reported at Oolagah Dam and in the Nowata area. Some freezing rain also occurred at the beginning of this event. ^In 1989, a bitter cold mass of Arctic air covered OK and AR. The high temperature for the day in Tulsa was only 7 degrees above zero, and the low was -6 degrees. Temperatures fell as low as 15 below zero in Miami, OK and Eureka Springs, AR the next morning.

In 1998, light freezing rain fell across southern OK and southern AR. While the worst of the ice was in north Texas, enough ice accumulated on roads in southeast OK and in parts of Sebastian County, AR to cause travel problems. ^In 2002, 5 to 10 inches of snow fell in a line from north of Tulsa to Fayetteville. Higher snow totals fell over northwest AR, including 15 inches at Rockhouse and 12 inches at Berryville.

In 1982, a 2-day tornado outbreak occurred from eastern OK through AR and southern MO from December 23-24. On the 24th, an F2 tornado injured 7 people in south Tulsa, and an F1 tornado injured 10 people near Ketchum, OK. ^In 2009, a blizzard struck northeast OK in the afternoon and evening. Heavy snow and wind gusts up to 40-60 mph reduced visibility to near zero for several hours and caused travel to be nearly impossible. Northeast OK received the greatest amount of snow with 4 to 6 inches common. Isolated totals of 6 to 10 inches were seen primarily in two separate bands, one from western Pawnee County into central Osage County and another from Okmulgee County into Craig County.

In 1914, snow fell over much of central and southern OK and northwest AR. 5 inches were observed in Eureka Springs, AR. ^In 1975, heavy snow fell in southeast OK and west central AR. Heavener, OK in LeFlore County received up to 15 inches of snow, and Fort Smith, Wilburton, and Sallisaw received 7 inches. Unofficial reports of up to 20 inches in the higher elevations of west central AR were received. Some trees and power lines were downed during the event. ^In 2012, A winter storm developed over the southern plains during the day bringing a mixture of winter weather to the area. Heavy snows fell over parts of Southeast OK and Western AR. Other areas received periods of light sleet and freezing rain. The Tulsa area missed out on most of the wintry precipitation only getting a little bit of freezing rain early Christmas morning.

In 1987, an ice storm occurred from December 25-27 in northeast OK and northwest AR. Significant icing occurred near the I-44 corridor in northeast OK. A 1900-foot TV tower near Tulsa collapsed, and 75,000 homes were without power, some for up to week. The storm caused $10 million in damages. Heavy rain also fell in southeast OK, causing flooding on the Poteau and Illinois Rivers and Brushy Creek in Pittsburg County.

In 1988, heavy snow fell in northeast OK and northwest AR. Up to 6 inches fell in Benton County, AR at Gravette, and 4 inches fell in Delaware, Sequoyah, Cherokee, and Mayes Counties. ^In 2000, a slow moving winter storm began on Christmas Day and continued through the 27th across eastern OK and northwest AR. 1 to 2 inches of ice accumulated, causing significant power outages (some 200,000 in Oklahoma and 10,000 customers in Arkansas) that lasted over a week in many locations. Areas in southeast OK, such as Pittsburg, Latimer, and LeFlore Counties, received the most damage.

In 2005, the lack of rainfall during the month of December made it the driest December in southeast OK since 1921.  Numerous fires spread across eastern OK during the last week of December. One wildfire burned 2000 acres west of Muskogee, and destroyed a car, house, and mobile home. Another wildfire burned over 1000 acres in Choctaw County. ^In 2019, a weak tornado touched down on the southeast side of Broken Arrow, OK. This brought the total number of tornadoes for 2019 in the NWS Tulsa CWA to 69, which is the second most confirmed in a single year.

In 1969, a potent winter storm struck eastern OK and northwest AR from the 29th to the 31st. Total snow accumulations of 4 to 10 inches fell in southeast OK through northwest AR, with freezing rain also causing significant damage in far southern sections. As much as 12 inches accumulated in Okmulgee, OK and 10 inches fell in Gravette, AR. 5 to 8 inches of snow fell in Bristow, Okemah, Fayetteville, and Tulsa. ^In 1972, a tornado hit 2 miles south of Ketchum, OK and tracked to 9 miles east of Miami. Significant damage occurred to at least one home near Ketchum. Straight line winds also tore thee roof off of a school in Warner, OK. ^In 1990, a strong arctic cold front caused temperatures to fall some 50 degrees through the day, with 1 to 2 inches of ice and sleet falling across northeast OK.

In 2006, an unusually moist air mass moved north into eastern OK ahead of a strong upper level low pressure system. This caused widespread thunderstorms across southeast Oklahoma, Some areas received 3 to 6 inches of rain, causing localized flooding in several counties such as Pittsburg, Latimer, Pushmataha, and Choctaw.

In 2000, a large area of moderate snow developed across central and eastern OK. Areas south and west  of a line from Tulsa to Fort Smith received the heaviest snowfall with amounts between 3 and 5 inches. ^In 2010, the town of Cincinnati, AR was struck by an F3 tornado in the early morning hours. The tornado started its path near Westville, OK and moved through Adair County into Arkansas. There were 4 fatalities and 7 injuries. ^2012 concluded as the warmest calendar year on record for Tulsa, Fort Smith and Fayetteville, as well as for the state of OK and for the entire United States!
